{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Sew an Invisible Zipper with Lining","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Give your handmade garment a professional fit by attaching an invisible zipper. This creates a seamless look so there aren't gaps near the closure. As long as you use an invisible zipper foot on your sewing machine, it's easy to attach the zipper to your dress, skirt, or shirt fabric. Once the zipper is in place, you can slip stitch the lining to the sides of the zipper. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Attaching the Zipper\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Attaching-the-Zipper\">Attaching the Zipper</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Sew a basting stitch along both sides of your garment's closure. Lay your garment right-side up and locate where you want to sew the zipper. Then, thread your sewing machine with a contrasting thread color and sew long, straight basting stitches about from the side edge of the opening where you'll put the zipper. Do this for the opposite side, too.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you prefer, sew the basting stitches by hand.</li> \n    <li>Since the basting stitch lines are simply guidelines, you're not actually sewing the fabric edges together. The lines just help you position the zipper so you sew it in straight.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Unzip the zipper and arrange the teeth of the left zipper to the left basting line. Take an invisible zipper that matches the color of your garment and unzip it all the way. Then, place the left zipper tape on the left side of your garment so the zipper teeth run directly on the basting stitch line.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> from the top of your garment, so you can tuck under and sew the top of the zipper.}}<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The flat side of the zipper should be laying flat on the right side of your garment.</li> \n    <li>If the zipper is bent or curled, lay it flat on an ironing board. Heat your iron to the synthetic setting and run it over the zipper tape to smooth it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pin the left zipper tape to your garment. Push a sewing pin through the tape horizontally so it secures the zipper to the edge of your garment. Keep checking to see that the zipper teeth line up on the basting stitch line as you go. Pin all the way to the bottom of the left zipper.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don't pin the right side of the zipper at this point. You'll attach the right-side zipper after you've finished sewing the left side in place.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach an invisible zipper foot and set the groove into the zipper teeth. Take the standard presser foot off of your sewing machine and push an invisible zipper foot onto the presser foot holder. Then, slide your fabric under the foot so the left groove fits onto the zipper teeth.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You'll see 2 grooves on the invisible zipper foot and your sewing needle will stitch in between them.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make straight stitches from the top down to the zipper stop. Set your machine to make standard straight stitches and begin sewing from the top of the left-side zipper. Stitch straight down until the invisible zipper foot reaches the zipper stop. Then, cut the thread and tie it off.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The invisible zipper foot glides along the zipper teeth as you sew, so this should only take a few seconds.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Repeat this for the opposite side of the zipper. Once you've sewn 1 side of the zipper in place, lay the other side of the zipper on the opposite edge of the garment. Arrange the zipper tape so the zipper's teeth line up with the basting stitch. Then, position your invisible zipper foot so right groove sits on the teeth and the needle is to the left. Sew straight stitches down to the zipper stop.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Zip the zipper and sew raw ends of the zipper tape. Tuck the top ends of the zipper tape under to hide the raw edges and sew them in place by hand. Then, use a needle and thread or your machine to sew the bottom tape end to the garment's seam allowance.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid sewing the bottom tape end to the fabric of the garment or your stitches will be visible.</li> \n    <li>If you can see the basting stitches when you turn your garment right-side-out, pull the basting stitches out.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Sewing Lining to an Invisible Zipper\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sewing-Lining-to-an-Invisible-Zipper\">Sewing Lining to an Invisible Zipper</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Turn the garment inside out so the zipper tape is visible. Once you've sewn the zipper to your garment, turn it inside out and lay it flat. This gives you easy access to the zipper tape, which is what you'll sew the lining onto.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Remember that the fabric side next to the zipper teeth is called the zipper tape.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fold your lining by and iron the crease flat. Take the lining that you've assembled for your item and read the pattern to find the seam allowance for the zipper opening. If the pattern doesn't specify, fold the part of the liner that fits around the zipper by . Then, use your iron to press the folded edges flat to make a crease.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Fold the pattern-side of the lining over towards the wrong side.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Arrange the lining right-side-up on the wrong side of your garment. Position the liner so the V-shaped zipper opening fits around the actual zipper. Line up the bottom of the zipper with the point of the liner where the edges meet.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This gives your garment straight, professional-looking seams.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pin both sides of the lining to the zipper tape. Hold the creased edge of the liner next to the zipper's teeth so the liner covers the zipper tape. Then, insert sewing pins horizontally along both sides of the zipper so the liner stays in place.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Ensure that you don't pin the liner over the teeth or your zipper will snag.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Slip stitch the liner to the zipper tape. To create invisible stitches, thread a sewing needle. Insert it through through the top edge of the zipper tape and bring the needle through the folded edge of the lining to make a stitch. Pull the thread and insert the needle back into the lining. Keep slip stitching between the folded lining and the zipper tape until you reach the bottom of the zipper.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Sew with the same thread that you used to sew the zipper to the garment.</li> \n    <li>Make your stitches about long, so they're short and strong.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sew slip stitches on the other side of the zipper tape and tie off the thread. Once you've secured the lining to 1 side of the zipper, start sewing along the other side. Work from the bottom of the liner at the base of the zipper up to the top. Then, tie off the thread and trim the excess.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>To make your zipper blend into your garment, pick a zipper that matches the color of the fabric.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Skirt, trousers, or dress</li> \n  <li>Zipper</li> \n  <li>Iron and ironing board</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li> \n  <li>Sewing needle</li> \n  <li>Sewing machine with an invisible zipper foot</li> \n  <li>Sewing pins</li> \n  <li>Liner fabric</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/qVYD3s8G8xU?t=1101\">https://youtu.be/qVYD3s8G8xU?t=1101</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/qVYD3s8G8xU?t=1158\">https://youtu.be/qVYD3s8G8xU?t=1158</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://sewguide.com/slip-stitch/\">https://sewguide.com/slip-stitch/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-an-Invisible-Zipper-with-Lining#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://sewguide.com/slip-stitch/\">https://sewguide.com/slip-stitch/</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 15 Sep 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"6c279508b6b18863f439b6ff35769eab","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"","publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627605},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Cut an Orange for Drinks","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Ah, oranges—the sweet, juicy fruit that just about everybody likes. In addition to being a great snack, oranges are also perfect for garnishing drinks, especially cocktails and certain types of beer like wheat beers and orange ales. Try experimenting with wedges, slices, wheels, and twists by adding them to different beverages for a garnish you’ll want to eat! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Creating Orange Wedges\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-Orange-Wedges\">Creating Orange Wedges</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wash the orange before you slice it. Rinse the orange peel under cool running water, and use your fingertips to thoroughly scrub the surface. There could be dirt or germs on the peel of the orange that could contaminate the knife and the orange slices if you don't wash it first.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut an Orange for Drinks Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be sure the knife is clean before you start cutting, also.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Slice the ends off the orange. Place the orange sideways in the middle of a cutting board. Use a sharp kitchen knife to cut the top and bottom off the orange to get rid of the stem and blossom end bits.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Hold the orange firmly when you do this, so it doesn't slip or roll while you're cutting.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>You can use either a chef’s knife or a paring knife for this, but it's easier if the knife is very sharp.</li> \n    <li>Be careful whenever you’re using a sharp knife. Keep your fingers and hands out from under the blade and always cut away from your body.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut the orange down the middle vertically. Hold the orange firmly with your thumb on one side and your fingers on the other side, so it doesn’t roll away while you cut it. Slice straight down through the middle, from the flat stem end to the flat blossom end.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut an Orange for Drinks Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Alternatively, you could stand the orange up on one of the flat ends and cut down through the middle from the top to bottom that way.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make 3 even diagonal cuts to cut each half into 3 wedges. Place the halves of the oranges flat-side-down on your cutting board. Slice into the peel diagonally from 1 side down to the middle of the fleshy side on the cutting board, then repeat this for the other side to cut the half into 3 even wedges. Do the same for the other half of the orange.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It might take a few tries to get the hang of cutting orange halves into 3 perfectly even wedges, but just keep practicing and you’ll be able to do it with no problem soon enough!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Slice a notch from the flesh to the peel in the middle of each wedge. Flip the wedges over so they are flesh-side-up on the cutting board. Cut down through the center of the flesh in each wedge until just before you reach the orange rind.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be careful not to cut all the way through the orange wedges. But don’t worry if you mess one up. You can always just eat your mistake!</li> \n    <li>If you want smaller wedges, you can cut each large wedge in half, then cut a notch into the middle of each of your smaller wedges.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stick the wedges on the rims of drink glasses to garnish them. Slide the notch you cut in an orange wedge over the rim of a glass until it sits there on its own. Try garnishing cocktails like <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Frozen-Margarita\" title=\"Make a Frozen Margarita\">Margaritas</a>, Dark and Stormies, and Bloody Marys. Stick the wedges on non-alcoholic beverages like fresh-squeezed orange juice, iced tea, and even glasses of ice water.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Other cocktails that go nicely with orange wedges are Pimm’s Cups and Gin Fizzes.</li> \n    <li>For a non-alcoholic treat, try adding an orange slice to a glass of ice water, lemon-lime soda, orange juice, or a frozen juice mocktail.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>When you’re drinking a beverage with an orange wedge garnish, you can squeeze the wedge into the drink for extra orange flavor. Or, you can just grab it off the rim and eat it!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Making Wheels and Slices\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Wheels-and-Slices\">Making Wheels and Slices</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut both ends off your orange. Place your orange sideways on a cutting board and hold it steady by the sides. Use a sharp chef’s knife or paring knife to cut the top and bottom ends off.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be careful when you’re slicing an orange with a sharp knife. Make sure you have a good grip on it, so it doesn’t slip or roll, and keep your fingers and hands out from under the knife’s blade.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Slice the orange into round slabs of the desired thickness, starting at one end. Hold the orange steady by the sides. Start cutting from one end by slicing straight down through the orange horizontally, keeping your fingers and hand that you’re holding the orange with out of the way as you cut. Keep slicing until you cut the whole orange into even wheels.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Wheels that are about thick are a good size for drinks if you’re not sure how big to make them.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut each wheel in half if you want orange slices for your drinks. Lay a wheel flat on your cutting board and cut right through the middle, so you have 2 even slices. Repeat this for each wheel to cut them all into even slices.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You could also leave half the orange in wheels and cut half the wheels into slices, if you want a variety of garnish options for drinks.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Slice a notch into your wheels or slices if you want to put them on glasses. Cut a notch from one side of each wheel into the middle of the wheel. Make a notch in the middle of the flesh of each slice that goes almost to the orange peel.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can skip this if you are planning to put the wheels or slices directly into a drink, rather than on the rim of a glass.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stick your wheels and wedges onto glasses or into glasses or pitchers. Try garnishing glasses containing cocktails or pints of beers like wheat beers or citrusy beers with the wedges and wheels. Toss some wheels or wedges right into pitchers of things like Margaritas or Sangria to decorate them and add some citrus flavor.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut an Orange for Drinks Step 11 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you make a pitcher of Screwdrivers with orange juice and vodka for brunch with your friends, you could throw some whole orange wheels directly into the pitcher. You can then use some slices to garnish individual glasses for serving.</li> \n    <li>You can also double-up on oranges in pints of beer by putting a wheel in the beer itself and sticking a wedge on the rim of the pint glass.</li> \n    <li>For a fun, tropical treat, try adding a slice of orange to a skewer along with other fruits like cherries and pineapples.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Cutting Orange Twists\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cutting-Orange-Twists\">Cutting Orange Twists</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut the bottom off an orange and place it cut-side-down on a cutting board. Hold an orange sideways on a cutting board and use a sharp knife to cut off just the bottom end. Stand the orange upright on the cutting board with the end you just cut flat against the board.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This just helps stabilize the orange while you cut the peel off to make a twist. Once you get comfortable with slicing the peel, you may choose to skip this step.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a paring knife to slice off a thin oval of the orange’s peel. Start at the top of the orange and just barely cut into the peel. Slice down and away from you until you cut off a thin, oval-shaped piece of the peel.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s OK if there is a bit of the pith, or the white rind, still attached to the peel, but it’s best not to have a big chunk of it. If there is, you can carefully slice the white pith away from the peel using your paring knife.</li> \n    <li>It’s up to you exactly how big to make your orange twist. Feel free to experiment with different oval sizes until you decide what works best for you and the drinks you’re making.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Twist the ends of the piece of peel in opposite directions using your fingertips. Pick up the oval-shaped piece of peel using 2-3 fingertips of both your hands. Twist your hands in opposite directions, so the oval curls up into a spiral shape.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This not only looks cool, but also releases the oils inside the peel to add aroma and flavor to your drink.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put the orange twist into a cocktail and serve the drink. Orange twists make nice garnishes for classic cocktails like Old Fashioneds or Orange Martinis. Simply drop the twist into the glass on top of the drink or lean it up against one side of the glass, so the rim supports it and it stands up.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut an Orange for Drinks Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-15.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Other cocktails you might want to garnish with an orange twist include the Tom Collins and the Sazerac.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Feel free to experiment with different wedge, wheel, and slice sizes. There really isn’t a right or wrong way to cut an orange for drinks!</li> \n  <li>If you have one, wear a cut-resistant glove on the hand you're using to hold the orange. That way, if the knife slips, you won't cut yourself.</li> \n  <li>Try combining oranges with other citrus fruits like lemons and limes in pitchers of Sangria or Margaritas. Or, you can add slices of other edible fruits like apples, peaches, and strawberries.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Be careful when you’re using a sharp knife to cut oranges for drinks. Keep your fingers and hands out of the way of the blade and always cut on a cutting board.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Cutting board</li> \n  <li>Sharp kitchen knife</li> \n  <li>Orange</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 13 Sep 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"cac4d4674076e3c6e12945c8e5b4339a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn63@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-03-48-046_37d66af795623cf4.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":40480,"destBytes":19508,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn63@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-03-48-046_37d66af795623cf4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn100@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-07-750_2e9eeb1d6ba43192.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn37@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-07-436_7e1633b0e4454376.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-15.jpg/aid12067267-v4-728px-Cut-an-Orange-for-Drinks-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn44@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-11-677_ae1c85121939a4c7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627601},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Sew Straight by Hand","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Everyone should have a few basic sewing skills and the straight stitch might be the best to learn. You don't need a sewing machine if you're stitching by hand. Instead, practice with a scrap of fabric, a sewing needle, and thread. Play around with sewing straight stitches that are different lengths before you try sewing a straight line. Your new skills will come in handy the next time you need to sew on a button, join a few pieces of fabric, or make a decorative border. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Making Straight Stitches\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Straight-Stitches\">Making Straight Stitches</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose a sewing needle and thread that matches the color of your fabric. If you can't find matching thread, use a slightly darker color so it doesn't stand out. You should be fine using a standard sharp sewing needle for most projects. Sharp needles are medium length and have a round eye which makes it easy to thread.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Sew Straight by Hand Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6d/Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg/aid12056966-v4-728px-Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Although sharp sewing needles work for most projects, you can use embroidery, beading, or tapestry needles depending on your project.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Thread the needle and tie a knot in the thread. Cut an length of thread and push 1 end through the eye of your sewing needle. Then, make a basic knot at the opposite end of the thread. You can knot it a few times if you want your thread to be more secure.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you struggle to thread the sewing needle, buy a needle threader. Push the pointed wire end of the threader into the eye of your needle and insert the thread through the gap. Then, pull the threader away from the needle so the thread works into the eye.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a ruler and chalk to draw a guideline for a perfectly straight line. To help you sew straight stitches, lay a ruler on your fabric where you want to create your stitch line. Then, run chalk along the edge to make a faint guideline that you can sew along.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You could also use a tailor's pencil or sewing pencil. Both of these have sharpened points that make marking simple and the markings are easy to get out of the fabric when you're done.</li> \n    <li>Pat the chalk marks off of the fabric with your hand or wash the material to remove tailor's pencil marks.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Bring the needle up from the bottom of the fabric. Hold your threaded needle on the wrong side of the fabric right where you want to make your straight stitch. Push the point of the needle up through the fabric. Keep pulling it straight up until the knot catches on the back of the fabric.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Pull the thread slowly through the fabric. If you pull it quickly, the thread can tangle and make a knot.</li> \n    <li>Don't pull too tightly when you feel the knot or you might accidentally pull the knot through the fabric.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Push the needle down to make 1 straight stitch about long. You can make your straight stitch any size you like. Try making stitches that are long for practice. Place the point of the needle on the surface of your fabric and push it through to the underside. Pull the needle underneath to draw all of the thread back down and make your straight stitch.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you leave a short space between your starting point, you'll get a tiny, strong stitch. If you make a long stitch, it will be quick to sew but won't be as sturdy as a short stitch. Long stitches are great for joining edges or making a noticeably dashed line.</li> \n    <li>Stitch length is completely customizable. Create a lot of short stitches if you want a secure line of stitches for embroidery or edges or make your stitches up to long.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Bring the needle back up to make another stitch that's the same length. Once you've made a straight stitch, push the needle back up through the fabric at the end of the stitch. Push your needle down through the fabric to make the next stitch just as long as the first stitch. Repeat the stitch as many times as you want.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Straight stitches are great for sewing edges of fabric together or making an outline for embroidery.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Customizing Your Straight Stitches\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Customizing-Your-Straight-Stitches\">Customizing Your Straight Stitches</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Work the running stitch to make a dashed line. Make a straight stitch that's as long as you want and leave a space that's the same size as the stitch. Then, bring your needle up and sew another stitch that's the same size as your first stitch. This creates a few straight stitches with a gap in between them.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Remember that you're stitching up and down to make the running stitch. Don't sew over the edge of your fabric or embroidery hoop or the thread will catch.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make backstitches to create a strong, straight line of stitches. If you'd like a bold line of stitches that are all connected, make 1 straight stitch. Then, push your needle up through the fabric so it's the same distance from the first stitch and bring the needle back and down through the end of the first stitch. Keep bringing the needle forward and back through the stitches.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The backstitch looks like the straight stitch that sewing machines make. It's great for outlining solid embroidery shapes or sewing words.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Create vertical straight stitches for the satin stitch. If you're filling an embroidered shape, make a short vertical stitch. Then, make another vertical stitch right next to the first stitch. Keep sewing the stitches so the edges overlap and create a smooth embroidered surface.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep your satin stitches less than wide or the stitches could snag.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>You don't have to make the thread blend into your fabric. For a fun embellishment that stands out, choose bold-colored thread that complements the fabric.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Be careful not to poke your fingers with the sharp needle. If you frequently stick yourself, put a thimble onto your index finger when you sew.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Thread</li> \n  <li>Sewing needle</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li> \n  <li>Fabric</li> \n  <li>Chalk or tailor's pencil, optional</li> \n  <li>Ruler, optional</li> \n  <li>Needle threader, optional</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Sew-Straight-by-Hand&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew\" title=\"Sew\">Sew</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-a-Scrunchie\" title=\"Sew a Scrunchie\">Sew a Scrunchie</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-a-Hem\" title=\"Sew a Hem\">Sew a Hem</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/DIY\" title=\"DIY\">DIY</a>\n   <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n    <ol class=\"references\"></ol>\n   </div></li>\n </ul> \n <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://sewguide.com/easy-hand-stitches/\">https://sewguide.com/easy-hand-stitches/</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/mJx4a67e3Pk?t=102\">https://youtu.be/mJx4a67e3Pk?t=102</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/bAmC5JNgK-s?t=264\">https://youtu.be/bAmC5JNgK-s?t=264</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://onstead.cvad.unt.edu/sites/default/files/1.2.7_sewing_doc_hand-sewing_seams.pdf\">https://onstead.cvad.unt.edu/sites/default/files/1.2.7_sewing_doc_hand-sewing_seams.pdf</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/bAmC5JNgK-s?t=301\">https://youtu.be/bAmC5JNgK-s?t=301</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/bAmC5JNgK-s?t=309\">https://youtu.be/bAmC5JNgK-s?t=309</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://sewguide.com/easy-hand-stitches/\">https://sewguide.com/easy-hand-stitches/</a></span> </li> \n <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew-Straight-by-Hand#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/go89e8xpVYs?t=233\">https://youtu.be/go89e8xpVYs?t=233</a></span> </li> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 13 Sep 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6d/Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg/aid12056966-v4-728px-Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"3e6433b7ce8ce1fca3a7433701847e71","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn9@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-03-48-073_b6ba347d24fbff37.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":50186,"destBytes":29940,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6d/Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg/aid12056966-v4-728px-Sew-Straight-by-Hand-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn9@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-03-48-073_b6ba347d24fbff37.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627574},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Tie Laces in a Double Knot","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>A double knot is a great way to keep your shoelaces tied, so you don’t have to worry about them coming undone and potentially tripping on them. You can also use a double knot when your shoelaces are too long to keep them from dragging or getting caught on something accidentally. To tie your laces in a double knot, start with a standard shoelace bow knot. Note that it will be difficult to make a double knot if your laces are very short after you tie them in a regular shoelace bow. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Making a Standard Double Knot\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-Standard-Double-Knot\">Making a Standard Double Knot</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Your-Shoes\" title=\"Tie Your Shoes\">Tie your shoelaces</a> in a standard bow knot. Make a loop with 1 end of the laces by doubling it back over itself. Wrap the other end of the laces around the base of the loop you made, then push it through the hole you just made by wrapping it and pull it into another loop. Pull both the loops in opposite directions to tighten the bow knot.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie Laces in a Double Knot Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12038218-v4-728px-Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For the best results when tying a double knot, make sure the loops and laces are even on both sides of your bow knot.</li> \n    <li>Use this method if you’re having problems with your laces coming undone all the time or if they’re too long and you want to keep the excess length out of the way.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pass the left loop over top of the right loop and wrap it around the back. Pinch the right loop between the thumb and forefinger of your right hand. Grab the left loop with the thumb and forefinger of your left hand, then wrap it on top of and around the back of the right loop.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is basically the same thing you did when you created the second loop for your standard bow knot, except this time you’re doing it with the loop you already made.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put the tip of the left loop through the hole created between the loops. Slip the left loop into the little hole that you made by wrapping it over and around the right loop. Push the tip of the loop through the hole until you can grab it from the other side.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you pull the left loop through the hole, you will be pulling it towards the right.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pull the loops in opposite directions to tighten the double knot. Grab the left loop, which is now going to the right, with your right hand and the right loop, which is now going to the left, with your left hand. Pull them firmly until the knot is tight.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To untie this standard double knot, just work your fingertips in between the knotted loops to loosen them up and pull them apart. After that, you can untie the standard bow knot as normal by pulling on the straight loose ends of the laces.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Creating an Easy-Release Double Knot\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-an-Easy-Release-Double-Knot\">Creating an Easy-Release Double Knot</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Make an overhand knot like you would to start a standard bow knot. Wrap the right lace over and under the left lace or vice versa. This is exactly the same as the first step of tying your laces into a normal bow knot.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use this method if you want a double knot that you can untie quickly by pulling on the laces instead of picking at them to loosen them.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Loop 1 end of the lace over the other end again in another overhand knot. Wrap the right lace over the left lace again or the left lace over the right lace again, depending on which way you wrapped them to start with. This is exactly the same as making the first overhand knot.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your laces will now look like a simple overhand knot with 3 loops in it, instead of the normal 2 loops.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make 2 bow loops just as if you’re tying a normal bow in your laces. Pinch the right end of the lace into a loop and wrap the left lace around it. Push the left lace though the space between the laces that you created by wrapping it, then pull it unto a second loop.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is exactly the same process as when you tie a standard bow knot.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wrap the left loop around the right loop and pull it through the hole it creates. Pass the left loop over the right loop and pull it around the back. Push it through the space between the 2 loops and pull it through to make a double knot.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is the same as tying a standard double knot. The thing that makes it quick-release is the additional overhand knot at the beginning.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Tighten the easy-release double knot by pulling on both loops. Grab the loops, 1 in each hand, and pull them in opposite directions. Stop pulling when the knot is all the way tight.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To untie this quick-release double knot, just pull firmly on one of the loose straight ends of the laces.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>A double knot is pretty bulky, so it’s great if you want to tie up some lengthy laces on something like a pair of hiking boots to keep them from dragging or prevent them from getting snagged on something in the woods.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Keep in mind that the standard double knot is not as fast to untie as a bow knot. If you want to be able to untie your laces and take off your shoes more quickly, go for an easy-release double knot.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-Laces-in-a-Double-Knot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section:
