13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Hide Your LinkedIn Profile","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>This wikiHow will teach you how to hide your public profile on LinkedIn so it does not appear in search results and make it un-viewable to people without a LinkedIn account. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Web Browser\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Web-Browser\">Using a Web Browser</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Go to <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://linkedin.com\">https://linkedin.com</a> and sign in. You can use any desktop browser to hide your Linkedin profile.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Click your profile picture. It's in the top row of navigational buttons with the button caption \"Me.\"\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-2.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Click . This is usually in the first grouping in the menu.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ad/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-3.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Click . You'll find this in the menu on the right side of the page above the header, \"People Also Viewed.\" You may need to click the Messaging tab to close it so you can see behind it.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-4.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Click to toggle the switch off next to \"Your profile's public visibility.<b>\"</b> It's under the \"Edit Visibility\" header on the right side of the page. \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-5.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using the Mobile App\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-the-Mobile-App\">Using the Mobile App</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Open LinkedIn. This app icon features \"in\" on a blue background that you can find on one of your Home screens, in the app drawer, or by searching.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-6.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap your profile picture. You'll find this in the top left corner of your screen.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-7.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap . It's next to \"View Profile\" at the top of the menu.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-8.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap . You'll see this tab running vertically across the top of your screen under the header, \"Settings.\"\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-9.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap . This is usually the first listing in the menu.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-10.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tap the switch to toggle it off next to \"Your profile's public visibility.<b>\"</b> It's under the \"Edit Visibility\" header.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hide Your LinkedIn Profile Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-11.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Any changes made here are saved automatically.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/90228/show-hide-and-edit-your-public-profile?lang=en</span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 15 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"720ab85140dc2facf665dba47dd6a1ff","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn25@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-04-500_7b67d5f3e2bb21cb.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":36326,"destBytes":14258,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn25@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-04-500_7b67d5f3e2bb21cb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-2.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn71@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-11-102_20b3d698a7b32bd8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ad/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-3.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-10-821_33365412fe5d8a30.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-4.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn21@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-06-187_5f9dee68955e0a39.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-5.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-07-157_be5a046f9b6817b1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-6.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn83@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-08-599_81397990865f9924.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-7.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn68@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-11-158_1b7ee1318ab2c797.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-8.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn24@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-08-785_81d1d175f0e218f4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-9.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn3@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-07-206_0911dad748fe66eb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-10.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn59@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-13-330_2a61d5b54537df58.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-11.jpg/aid12089051-v4-728px-Hide-Your-LinkedIn-Profile-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn4@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-08-824_b094e0e51f379bdd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627607},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Use a Paint Brush","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>The key to a good paint job is to use high quality paint and a good paint brush. Buy the best brush you can afford and make sure it's the right kind for the type of paint you're using. Latex brushes don't work well with oil paints, nor do oil brushes work with water-based paints.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Once you have the right brush, you can focus on technique! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Loading a Paintbrush\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Loading-a-Paintbrush\">Loading a Paintbrush</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose an artist’s brush if you’re making art or adding details. If you’re making art, pick up a set of artist’s brushes in a variety of sizes and shapes. Each style of brush is unique and creates a different type of line. The brushes you choose for a particular painting are entirely up to you, but it helps to have options. You can also use an artist’s brush to paint small surfaces or add fill in details on a wall if you’re repainting your home.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You also have a choice between synthetic and natural brushes. Generally speaking, natural bristles are best for oil paint, while synthetic is best for acrylic and watercolor paint.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a painter’s brush if you’re painting interior walls or large surfaces. Painter’s brushes refer to the paintbrushes are typically used by interior painters. They’re usually wide and they usually have a unique hourglass-shaped handle. If you’re repainting your home or business, grab a painter’s brush. Artists often use painter brushes to repaint canvases, apply primer, or add large sections of color.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use a natural brush for oil-based paints and primers. Use a synthetic brush for latex paints. Synthetic painter’s brushes are almost always made out of nylon.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Dampen the brush with water or mineral spirits to prepare it. If you’re using acrylic, latex, or watercolor paint, dip your brush’s bristles in water. If you’re using an oil paint, dip the bristles in mineral spirits. This will make the paint stick to your bristles for longer and reduce how often you need to reload the brush. It will also make cleaning the brush easier.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Blot the bristles with a dry cloth after you dip them to keep them from dripping with water or mineral spirits. You don’t want them to be soaked, just a little damp.</li> \n    <li>Artist and painter brushes are loaded the same way. There’s no real difference between them when it comes to loading them with paint.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lower the bristles half way into the paint to load them up. Pour your paint in a paint tray or squirt your colors out on your easel. To load your paintbrush, dip the bristles halfway into the paint. You only use the front half of the bristles to apply paint, so all you’re doing is making the bristles harder to clean if you load them up all the way.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Remember to mix the paint before using it if you’re using an interior paint that comes in a can or large bucket. The pigments tend to separate in these paints while they’re sitting on the shelf.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use the easel or paint tray to knock the excess paint off. Take the bristles out of the paint. Then, if you’re using a paint tray or can, drag the bristles against the rim on each side of the brush to knock off some of the paint. If you’re using an easel, drag the bristles back and forth next to your dollop of paint. This will remove the excess paint and keep your brush from dripping as you paint.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t do this, your brush may drip while you’re moving it. Your first brush stroke will also be saturated in paint and it won’t match the rest of the brush stroke.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Working with a Painter’s Brush\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Working-with-a-Painter’s-Brush\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Working-with-a-Painter.E2.80.99s-Brush\">Working with a Painter’s Brush</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Brace the sides of the brush if you’re covering a large, flat surface. If you’re painting a flat surface and there are no edges or corners nearby, hold the brush by the ferrule, which is the metal collar under the bristles. Put your thumb on one side and brace the other side with your four fingers. This grip is great because you won’t get sore quickly.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You have to apply a fair bit of pressure to cover a large surface area in paint. If you hold the brush by the handle, your wrist will get sore pretty quickly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Grip angle brushes by the junction of the ferrule for cuts and edges. For more precise cuts where the angle of the bristles matters a great deal, lay your thumb on the side right above the edge of the ferrule. Then, slide your index finger on top of the handle like you’re holding a pencil. Grip the sides of the brush with your 3 free fingers to balance it.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>In painting, a “cut” refers to a straight line where 2 colors meet. When you paint the edges of a wall around the trim, it is called “cutting in.”</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Line the brush’s bristles up with the surface you’re painting. If you’re using a flat brush, press the bristles straight against the surface. If you’re using an angle brush, tilt the brush so the bristles line up with the surface. You can turn angle brushes so the angle is skinny and leave a thick bead of paint, or hold it vertically to spread a wider line of paint.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the bristles aren’t flat against the surface of the wall, your line won’t be even. Part of it will look too thin and part of the line will look too rich and thick.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Press the bristles against the surface and drag your arm to apply paint. Apply a light amount of pressure to the surface with your bristles. Then, keep your wrist steady and move your entire arm along the line you’re painting to apply the paint.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s actually pretty hard to get a straight line if you only move your wrist. Moving your entire arm ensures that your brush doesn’t shake as you move it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drag the bristles at a 45-degree angle to the surface you’re painting. While you’re moving your arm, soften your grip up a little bit and let the bristles drag behind your wrist while you paint. If you only use the tip of the bristles, you’ll need to reload your brush every 2-3 seconds. By letting the brush drag at an angle, a larger percentage of the bristles will brush against the surface.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Cover each section you paint 2-3 times to smooth out the texture. Once you reach the end of a line, move the brush back in the opposite direction. This will apply another layer of paint from the other side of the bristles and fill in any small areas you missed the first time you painted the line. Reload your brush and continue painting.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Creating Art with an Artist’s Brush\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Creating-Art-with-an-Artist’s-Brush\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-Art-with-an-Artist.E2.80.99s-Brush\">Creating Art with an Artist’s Brush</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Use a pencil grip to hold a standard brush for precise strokes. The best way to hold an artist’s brush is to grip it on one side with your thumb and the other side with your index finger. Curl your three remaining fingers underneath the brush to brace it and keep it balanced.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-12.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is the most common grip, but it’s fine if you find another grip that’s more comfortable for you. There is no right or wrong way to hold a brush if you’re making art!</li> \n    <li>Some artists prefer to hold the end of the brush and lay their index finger on top to control the brush.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clutch the brush behind the ferrule to balance it. Unlike a pencil, you do not hold an artist’s brush behind the bristles. Instead, slide your fingers away from the metal part of the brush, called the ferrule. It’s hard to see what you’re doing if your hand is on the ferrule and you’re more likely to brush the wet paint with the side of your palm if you hold it near the tip.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-13.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s much easier to balance the brush in your hand and control it if you hold it near the center of gravity in the middle of the brush. The reason you can’t do this with a pencil or pen is because you need to apply pressure when you use a writing tool. You don’t really need to do that with a brush, though!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drag your wrist slowly to apply paint in straight lines. Press the tip of the bristles into the surface you’re painting and keep your wrist as steady as possible. Move your entire arm at the same time to paint a straight line. Keep the bristles at the same distance to the surface you’re painting to avoid changing the thickness of the line.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can totally change the distance of the bristles if you want to intentionally change the thickness of the line mid-stroke!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Flick the bristles with your wrist to add textures or details. For smaller flourishes of color or minor highlights, hold the bristles against the surface and move your wrist in the direction you’re adding the paint to add a quick dash of color that doesn’t look like a thick, full line. Do this over and over again to build up textures or add color.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is the best way to build up clouds, grass, tree trunks, or textured backgrounds.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Touch the canvas or paper with the very tip of the brush for minor additions. If you ever want to add a small dot or line, only touch the surface with the very tip of your bristles. You can either flick your wrist or move your arm to apply the line. This takes some practice to get the thickness of your marks right, but you’ll improve the more you paint.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Build your composition up with a variety of strokes to add depth. Use a variety of different strokes and movements to develop your work. Painters rarely rely on a single type of brush stroke, so mix it up and find a pattern that works for you. Alternate between different brush sizes and shapes to develop a full repertoire that makes your paintings pop.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Caring for Paintbrushes\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Caring-for-Paintbrushes\">Caring for Paintbrushes</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Clean off your paintbrush immediately after each use. If you don’t clean your brush immediately after using it, the paint will dry on the bristles and you’ll end up with a stiff, unusable brush. While it’s fine to keep it wet for 5-10 minutes while you clean up, you really don’t want to wait too long to clean your brushes.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-18.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The one exception here is if you used oil-based primer. This stuff is extremely hard to clean and you’re better off using a cheap disposable brush if you’re working with oil-based primer.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use mineral spirits or turpentine to remove oil-based paint. If you were using oil paint, fill a small plastic cup with mineral spirits or turpentine. Submerge the bristles and shake the brush around in the liquid to remove the larger chunks of paint. Do this for 2-3 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Oil paint is typically harder to remove than acrylic or latex paint. You may need to do this 2-3 times to really get your brush clean.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pour soap and hot water on the bristles get rid of acrylic or latex paint. If you were using latex, acrylic, or watercolor paint, run your brush under warm water. Squirt 1-2 dollops of dish soap on the bristles and gently spread the soap out by hand. Run the bristles against the edge of your sink like you’re painting it while letting the water run to get rid of most of the paint.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t worry about staining your sink. Latex, acrylic, and watercolor are all water-based paints and will wash off so long as you don’t let the paint dry.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Shake or spin your brush while rinsing it until the water runs clear. Whether you were using mineral spirits, turpentine, or soap, take your brush and hold it under warm water. Press the bristles flat at an angle to wash each side of the bristles. Flip the bristles up and let the water pour into them directly. Once the water starts running clear, shake or spin the brush between your palms to shake out the excess moisture.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Let your brush air dry on a cloth or newspaper. Lay the brush flat on a clean cloth or stack of newspaper and let it air out for 2-3 hours. Once the brush is completely dry, put it back wherever you’re storing it to put it back in your brush rotation.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-22.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Paint Brush Step 22.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-22.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-22.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Painter’s tape is a great tool to have on hand if you’re painting interior walls or trying to paint a perfectly straight line. Just lay the tape down against the edge where you want the paint to stop and paint over the seam where it meets your surface.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you don’t clean your brushes after using them, the paint will harden and you may have to throw your brush out. You can try restoring the brush by soaking it in fabric softener or paint thinner, but this won’t always work.<sup id=\"_ref-25\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 25\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_note-25\">[25]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>When you clean your brushes, do not push the bristles hard into the sink you’re using to clean it. This may damage the shape of the bristles permanently.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Water</li> \n  <li>Paint tray</li> \n  <li>Easel</li> \n  <li>Soap</li> \n  <li>Water</li> \n  <li>Mineral spirits</li> \n  <li>Turpentine (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Roller\" title=\"Use a Paint Roller\">Use a Paint Roller</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Paintbrush\" title=\"Clean a Paintbrush\">Clean a Paintbrush</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-a-Room\" title=\"Paint a Room\">Paint a Room</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Prepare-a-Room-for-Painting\" title=\"Prepare a Room for Painting\">Prepare a Room for Painting</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Climb-a-Ladder-Safely\" title=\"Climb a Ladder Safely\">Climb a Ladder Safely</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Clean-Paint-Edges-on-Interior-Walls\" title=\"Create Clean Paint Edges on Interior Walls\">Create Clean Paint Edges on Interior Walls</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Paint-Brush&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.sherwin-williams.com/homeowners/sw-article-dir-intchoosebrush\">https://www.sherwin-williams.com/homeowners/sw-article-dir-intchoosebrush</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-10-types-paintbrushes-artist\">https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-10-types-paintbrushes-artist</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.bobvila.com/articles/best-paint-brushes/\">https://www.bobvila.com/articles/best-paint-brushes/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Paint-Brush#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.thisoldhouse.com/painting/21017279/how-to-use-a-paint-brush\">https://www.thisoldhouse.com/painting/21017279/how-to-use-a-paint-brush</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-5\"><a \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Sep 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"a69aeb7a2273ff3331bccd7aec183af5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn3@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-03-56-036_3f3b4670ffa86bb9.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":24455,"destBytes":12294,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn3@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-03-56-036_3f3b4670ffa86bb9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn18@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-06-275_2be1c8eccc06d802.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn21@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-06-173_7f1b53867a7b991f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn43@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-07-473_ab202c210a6921d0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn8@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-07-504_98a6e2c7511abc9b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-12.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn51@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-10-066_1f11905591622561.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-13.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-07-470_03863323726dd978.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-18.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn75@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-10-345_86e287ed22034f7a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-22.jpg/aid97577-v4-728px-Use-a-Paint-Brush-Step-22.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn18@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-06-173_43a0428e5d0ac51a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627592},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Weighted blankets, or gravity blankets, apply a light, even pressure over your entire body, similar to a gentle hug. This deep pressure stimulation creates a calming effect that can lower anxiety and help you toss and turn less so you get a better night’s sleep and wake up feeling refreshed. While there’s no guarantee that a weighted blanket will work for you, research shows that many people benefit from one, so feel free to try it out! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Figuring Out If a Weighted Blanket Is Right for You\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Figuring-Out-If-a-Weighted-Blanket-Is-Right-for-You\">Figuring Out If a Weighted Blanket Is Right for You</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Try a weighted blanket if you have an anxiety disorder or panic disorder. The weight of the blanket simulates “deep touch pressure,” which affects your nervous system by increasing your body’s production of both serotonin and oxytocin. This increases relaxation so you get a great night’s sleep.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A weighted blanket can also decrease your cortisol levels so you feel less stressed.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Some people describe a weighted blanket as a “hug machine.”</li> \n    <li>To reduce your anxiety even further, do some meditation before bed.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a weighted blanket if you are restless or have insomnia. The gentle pressure of a weighted blanket can limit how often you toss and turn at night, leading to more restful sleep.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> Similarly, if you suffer from insomnia, the blanket can help you feel more settled so you get a good night’s sleep.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Ask your pediatrician if a weighted blanket is right for your child. There’s some evidence that a weighted blanket can help children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or those on the Autism spectrum relax and calm down.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> However, there’s also some concern about the safety of weighted blankets for children and there have been some deaths associated with them due to suffocation.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> Chat with your child’s doctor to find out if a weighted blanket would be a good choice for your little one.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You could try giving your child a weighted blanket to help them fall asleep. Check on them frequently and swap out the blanket for a regular one once they’re snoozing.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Don’t put a weighted blanket over a child that cannot remove it themselves.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Never put a weighted blanket on a baby under 1 year.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Avoid using a weighted blanket if you have a sleep disorder or other health problems. Unfortunately, it’s best not to use a weighted blanket if you suffer from obstructive sleep apnea or have asthma.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Similarly, don’t use a weighted blanket if you have cardiac issues, epilepsy, or circulatory problems.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stick with a regular blanket if you’re claustrophobic. If you have a fear of small spaces, a weighted blanket could trigger you. Feel free to try one out, but it might not be a good option for you.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Weighted Blanket\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Weighted-Blanket\">Using a Weighted Blanket</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Get a blanket that weighs . These blankets are available in a range of different weights, from . Studies show that a blanket with a weight of is optimal for adults as it creates a light pressure while keeping you from getting too warm at night.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If a blanket doesn’t work for you, choose one that weighs between 5 and 10% of your body weight.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Choose a blanket with materials that are comfortable for you. Weighted blankets are filled with different materials depending on the manufacturer. Some have glass beads while others have metal or plastic pellets.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup> Check out a few in-person to figure out which you find the most comfortable, as this is a matter of personal preference.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Consider how easy the blanket is to wash, too!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wear lighter or fewer clothes if you get hot at night. Since a heavier blanket can keep you warmer, skip the flannel pajamas and choose clothes that are thin and lightweight. Or, sleep in your birthday suit!<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Make sure the blanket doesn’t hang off the edge of your bed. These blankets come in different sizes. Get a blanket that fits over your body but isn’t too large—it shouldn’t hang over your bed.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Getting Great Sleep\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-Great-Sleep\">Getting Great Sleep</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Aim for 7-8 hours of sleep per night. As an adult, you need about 8 hours of sleep per night. Teens need 9-10, younger kids need at least 10, preschoolers need up to 12, and babies need between 16 and 18 hours every night.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Not getting enough sleep can make you irritable, depressed, or anxious. It also affects your cognitive skills and reaction times, so get those z’s in!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wake up and go to bed at the same time every day. Creating a regular sleep schedule is actually pretty important and can improve the quality of your sleep. Make a schedule that works for you and stick to it—even on weekends and holidays.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, you might go to bed at 10 pm and wake up at 6 am. If you’re more of a night owl with a flexible schedule, go to sleep at midnight and get up at 8.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Have your last meal a few hours before bed. Eating a heavy meal too close to bedtime isn’t a great idea. You don’t want to be too hungry or too full when you lay down, so eat dinner a few hours before bed and avoid late-night snacking. Similarly, drink a little bit so you’re not thirsty, but not so much that you’ll need to get up to use the bathroom frequently.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Stay away from caffeine and nicotine in the evening, as well.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make your bedroom cool, dark, and comfortable. You won’t sleep well if you’re too hot or if your room is bright. Turn down the thermostat or use a fan at night and hang up some light-blocking shades to keep the sunlight from filtering into your room.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can even use earplugs or a white noise machine if you like.</li> \n    <li>Try to avoid watching TV in bed or scrolling on your phone. The blue light can make it harder to fall asleep.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Exercise every day. Being active during the day can help you sleep longer and better. Try to get some exercise every day, but don’t do strenuous workouts before you hit the hay—exercising within 2 hours of bedtime could actually negatively impact your sleep.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Minimize your stress. If you’ve got a lot on your mind, it could be hard to fall asleep. Take a few minutes to write down anything you need to take care of as well as any stresses. Then, set aside your list to tackle the next day.<sup id=\"_ref-25\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 25\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-25\">[25]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Weighted Blanket for Better Sleep Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid12048013-v4-728px-Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do some restful activities before bed, like meditating or taking a bath.<sup id=\"_ref-26\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 26\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-26\">[26]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you and your pediatrician decide that a heavy blanket isn’t a good choice for your child, try using a weighted vest during the day time, instead.<sup id=\"_ref-27\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 27\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep#_note-27\">[27]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Weighted-Blanket-for-Better-Sleep&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol
