\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 15 Sep 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Grill-Zucchini.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini.jpg","linkMd5":"4ed7105f6ed978ba93fbe10f22f5b27e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn21@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-03-48-184_4e575b77ec74c215.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":273,"sourceBytes":38841,"destBytes":26238,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Grill-Zucchini.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn21@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-03-48-184_4e575b77ec74c215.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Grill-Zucchini-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn47@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-09-185_98bb6699dfefcadc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Grill-Zucchini-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn15@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-11-580_4169cdad0e224766.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Grill-Zucchini-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn7@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-12-164_42cc57ed047fc445.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Grill-Zucchini-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn87@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-12-252_a855b432bd6f0679.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Grill-Zucchini-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn11@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-09-711_57814c3cab5c2083.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Grill-Zucchini-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-11-572_27326133a19e00de.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Grill-Zucchini-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn7@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-10-652_0c6218682a643397.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Grill-Zucchini-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn88@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-07-722_b9d194fa85bf4951.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Grill-Zucchini-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn28@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-10-210_619beaf5c196dff7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Grill-Zucchini-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn63@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-08-493_b1feb192f0604a62.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Grill-Zucchini-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid4346099-v4-728px-Grill-Zucchini-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn47@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-12-512_ffd2ccec04d160cb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627606},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Make Clear Glue","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Don't rush out to the store the next time you run out of glue! With a few pantry items, you can make simple homemade craft glue that dries completely clear. While most homemade glue recipes contain flour as a binder, you can make a flour-free glue using cornstarch. If you're short on time and don't want to cook the glue, just mix flour with water to make a quick paste. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Basic Craft Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Basic-Craft-Glue\">Basic Craft Glue</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>1 cup (120 g) of all-purpose flour</li> \n  <li>1/3 cup (67 g) of sugar</li> \n  <li>cup water, divided</li> \n  <li>of vinegar</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes of glue</i> </p> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Flour-Free Clear Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Flour-Free-Clear-Glue\">Flour-Free Clear Glue</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>cup water, divided</li> \n  <li>2 tablespoons (40 g) of corn syrup</li> \n  <li>of vinegar</li> \n  <li>2 tablespoons (15 g) of cornstarch</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes of glue</i> </p> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: No-Cook Clear Paste or Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"No-Cook-Clear-Paste-or-Glue\">No-Cook Clear Paste or Glue</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>2 tablespoons (16 g) of all-purpose flour</li> \n  <li>of water</li> \n  <li>1 pinch of salt</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes of glue</i> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Basic Craft Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Basic-Craft-Glue_2\">Basic Craft Glue</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Whisk flour with sugar and of the water. Put a saucepan on the stove and pour 1 cup (120 g) of all-purpose flour into it along with 1/3 cup (67 g) of sugar and of the water. Whisk the mixture to make a smooth paste.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Clear Glue Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don't worry if you see a few lumps since you can strain them out later.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir in the remaining of water and vinegar. Slowly pour in the rest of the water while you whisk. Then, mix in of vinegar. The vinegar is a very mild preservative that helps your homemade glue last a little longer.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It doesn't matter which type of vinegar you use, especially since you won't smell the vinegar after you cook and cool the glue.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Heat the glue over medium and simmer it for 5 minutes. Turn the burner to medium and whisk the glue while it cooks. Keep whisking as it bubbles gently and cook the glue until it's thick.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Although the glue looks white, it dries clear so it's great for most craft projects.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Strain the glue into an airtight storage container. Turn off the burner and set a fine-mesh strainer over your storage container. Carefully spoon the glue into the strainer and push it through using the back of the spoon. Then, use the glue or put the lid on it and store it at room temperature for up to 2 days.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Clear-Glue-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Clear Glue Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your glue doesn't look lumpy, you can skip this step and transfer the glue directly to your storage container.</li> \n    <li>Clean the saucepan and strainer in hot, soapy water as soon as you finish making the glue. Once you've used the glue in the container, soak it for 30 minutes before scrubbing it with hot, soapy water.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Flour-Free Clear Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Flour-Free-Clear-Glue_2\">Flour-Free Clear Glue</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mix of the water with corn syrup and vinegar. Set a saucepan on the stove and pour in of the water. Add 2 tablespoons (40 g) of corn syrup and of vinegar. Then, stir the mixture until the corn syrup dissolves.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use any type of vinegar in this glue recipe.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat. Turn the burner to medium and keep the lid off of the pan so you can see when the liquid begins to boil. Stir the mixture occasionally and heat it until it comes to a full rolling boil.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Clear-Glue-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Clear Glue Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mix the remaining water with cornstarch in a small bowl. Pour the remaining of water into a small mixing bowl and add 2 tablespoons (15 g) of cornstarch. Use a spoon or a whisk to mix the cornstarch until it dissolves in the water.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The cornstarch makes the glue thick and easier to spread.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Whisk the cornstarch into the pan and boil it for 1 minute. Slowly pour the cornstarch mixture into the pan with the boiling liquid. Keep whisking the whole time you pour so the cornstarch doesn't clump. Bring the glue to a boil and continue to whisk for 1 minute.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It's really important to whisk constantly so the glue becomes smooth.</li> \n    <li>Wash the pan immediately in hot, soapy water so the glue doesn't have a chance to harden.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Turn off the burner and cool the glue to room temperature. Set the pan on a cool burner so the glue stops cooking and leave it to sit until it's cool enough to handle. This should take around 20 minutes. Then, use your glue or store it for later.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Clear-Glue-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Clear Glue Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To store the flour-free glue, spoon it into an airtight container and keep it at room temperature for up to 2 days.</li> \n    <li>Once you've used the glue and need to clean the container, soak it in hot, soapy water for 30 minutes before you scrub it out.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: No-Cook Clear Paste or Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"No-Cook-Clear-Paste-or-Glue_2\">No-Cook Clear Paste or Glue</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Put 2 tablespoons (16 g) of flour into an airtight container. Find a small container that you'd like to use to store the glue and put the flour into it. If you'd like to double or triple the recipe, use a larger container.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Since this glue only lasts 1 day, make just as much as you need for your project.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir in of water and 1 pinch of salt. Slowly whisk in the water 1 spoonful at a time to prevent large lumps from forming. Then, mix in a pinch of salt. Keep mixing until the flour is hydrated and you have a sticky paste.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Whisk in more water until the glue is the consistency you want. If you'd like a clear paste, you may not need to add more water. To make thinner glue that you can spread with a brush, whisk in a spoonful of water at a time.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Add up to an extra of water for thin, clear glue.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Refrigerate the glue for 10 to 15 minutes if you want to make thick paste. Although you can use the clear glue as soon as you've mixed it, stick it in the fridge to chill if you want a thicker paste. Then, stick a popsicle or craft stick into the paste to spread it on your project.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Clear-Glue-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Clear Glue Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Store your no-cook glue or paste at room temperature for up to 1 day. If you keep it in the fridge for more than 15 minutes, it will dry out and harden.</li> \n    <li>To clean out the container, soak it in hot, soapy water for 30 minutes before you wash it.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>To make a mixture that's not as thick or sticky as glue, create your own <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Slime\" title=\"Make Clear Slime\">clear slime</a>!</li> \n  <li>Homemade glue doesn't last as long as storebought glue with preservatives, so use the glue within a few days.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Basic Craft Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Basic-Craft-Glue_3\">Basic Craft Glue</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Measuring cups and spoons</li> \n  <li>Saucepan</li> \n  <li>Whisk</li> \n  <li>Spoon</li> \n  <li>Fine-mesh strainer</li> \n  <li>Storage container</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Flour-Free Clear Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Flour-Free-Clear-Glue_3\">Flour-Free Clear Glue</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Measuring cups and spoons</li> \n  <li>Saucepan</li> \n  <li>Whisk</li> \n  <li>Spoon</li> \n  <li>Storage container</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: No-Cook Clear Paste or Glue\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"No-Cook-Clear-Paste-or-Glue_3\">No-Cook Clear Paste or Glue</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Storage container</li> \n  <li>Spoon</li> \n  <li>Measuring spoon</li> \n  <li>Whisk, optional</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Clear-Glue&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Clear-Glue#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/_yRtiYOfpWM?t=21\">https://youtu.be/_yRtiYOfpWM?t=21</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://youtu.be/_yRtiYOfpWM?t=86\">https://youtu.be/_yRtiYOfpWM?t=86</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.thoughtco.com/homemade-glue-recipes-607826\">https://www.thoughtco.com/homemade-glue-recipes-607826</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 14 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"6bea8bee34a3ac0acbb6abb04fd35742","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn34@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-03-47-977_334839c11b74a394.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":51324,"destBytes":31332,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn34@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-03-47-977_334839c11b74a394.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn79@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-10-549_b603fafc325779e2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-06-225_8abff7918f64082a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn48@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-10-691_5961587c1a9da852.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Make-Clear-Glue-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid12046899-v4-728px-Make-Clear-Glue-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn80@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-12-060_36c3ead6f85757c9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627591},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Keep Meat Moist in the Oven","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>It can be so disappointing to spend time and resources on preparing a delicious meal, only to find that the meat has dried out while it was cooking in the oven. Delightfully, though, there are plenty of ways to help keep meat moist, tender, and juicy while it bakes. With a little bit of research and preparation, you can ensure that your next roast chicken or oven-baked steak comes out perfect! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Choosing and Preparing Meat\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Choosing-and-Preparing-Meat\">Choosing and Preparing Meat</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose dark, fatty meat for the juiciest results. When choosing which cut of meat to cook, the ones that have the most fat will be the most tender and moist. For chicken and turkey, focus on the thighs and legs. With red meat, look for marbled steaks, or consider mixing in other forms of fat if you’re making something like meatballs. For roasts, pick the tenderloin from beef or pork.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Meat Moist in the Oven Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, pancetta, milk, eggs, and cheese are great to incorporate to things like meatballs or meatloaf, as they’ll add moisture to the meal.</li> \n    <li>If you’re making chicken meatballs from ground chicken, add in small pieces of dark meat to help keep them moist as they cook.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take meat out of the fridge 15-30 minutes before it needs to go in the oven. Putting meat straight from the fridge into the oven could result in food that is done on the outside but unevenly cooked on the inside. Make it a habit to put it on the counter while you’re prepping the rest of your meal.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Meat Moist in the Oven Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-2.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Of course, you don’t want to leave raw meat on the counter for too long. If you aren’t going to cook soon, pop it back into the fridge within 2 hours. If you live in a warmer climate, it’ll need to go into the fridge sooner.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pound chicken breasts or pork chops to a thin layer so they cook evenly. Place the breast between 2 pieces of plastic wrap or into a resealable plastic bag. Use the flat side of a meat tenderizer to gently pound on them until they’re an even width all the way across. This method helps the breast to cook fully without drying out anywhere.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This method doesn’t work for bone-in chicken breasts.</li> \n    <li>If you don’t have a meat tenderizer, you could use a bottle of wine, rolling pin, or even the flat side of a skillet.</li> \n    <li>This works for turkey breasts, too.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stuff the skin of a chicken or turkey with butter to get a tender interior. This works especially well when you’re roasting an entire bird, but you can do it to any piece of poultry as long as it still has its skin on. Mix softened butter, seasonings, and herbs in a small bowl. Use your fingers to carefully push the mixture underneath the skin and spread it around before cooking.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This method results in crispy skin and juicy meat. of olive oil, 1 tbsp (10 grams) of garlic powder, 1 tbsp (1.7 grams) of fresh rosemary, 1 tsp (1 gram) of dried oregano, 1 tbsp (3.8 grams) of fresh parsley, 2 tsp (5 grams) of onion powder, 1 tsp (1.8 grams) of crushed red chili pepper flakes, 1 1/2 tsp (2.4 grams) of ground cumin, and salt and pepper.}}</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Brine raw lean meat to help it retain its juices while it cooks in the oven. For a quick brine while you prepare the rest of dinner, combine 1/4 cup (75 grams) of kosher salt with of warm water and stir until the salt has dissolved. Submerge the meat in the brine and let it sit for about 1-2 hours. Remove it from the brine and pat it dry before cooking it.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use enough water to cover the piece of meat entirely. For each quart (4 cups) of water, remember to use 1/4 cup (75 grams) of salt. 3-4 sprigs of each fresh herb or 1 tablespoon of each dried herb can be added for each quart (4 cups) of water, too.</li> \n    <li>Your brine can be as simple as salt and water, or you could add either fresh or dried herbs and seasonings, like thyme, rosemary, parsley, sage, garlic, and black pepper. You could also brine meat in milk or yogurt to give it a slightly tangy flavor.</li> \n    <li>You can brine <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Brine-Chicken\" title=\"Brine Chicken\">chicken</a>, shrimp, fish, pork chops, and other lean cuts of meat.</li> \n    <li>For red meats, like steak, try dry-brining. Instead of mixing salt and water, you just rub seasonings on the meat directly and let it sit for several hours before cooking it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Baste meat every 30 minutes while it cooks to keep it moist. When meat gets hot in the oven, it starts to leak juices, fat, and oil—things that would normally keep it very moist. Use a large spoon or a bulb baster to carefully pour those juices back over the meat. This should help keep it from drying out and make it more flavorful.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is especially helpful for larger selections of meat, like roasts, but you can also use it on steak, pork chops, or even a simple chicken breast.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using Specific Cooking Techniques\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Specific-Cooking-Techniques\">Using Specific Cooking Techniques</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cook tough cuts of meat at a low temperature over a longer period of time. With the tougher cuts, like beef chuck, pork shoulder, and brisket, consider using them in a slow-roasted or braised dish. Basically, the longer it gets to cook, the more tender the meat will get.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These types of meat generally need a minimum of an hour to cook.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sear tender cuts of meat and cook them at a higher temperature. Pieces like chicken breasts, pork chops, and tenderloin tend to dry out quickly if they’re cooked for too long. Sear each side of the meat on a super hot pan, and then pop it into a preheated oven for a few minutes or finish it on the stovetop.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Searing doesn’t actually “lock in moisture,” but it does help create more dynamic flavor! Since these cuts of meat don’t take long to cook and have less time to develop a deep flavor profile, the searing helps add caramelization and complexity to the dish.</li> \n    <li>Make sure the meat is completely dry before you try to sear it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Reverse-Sear-Meat\" title=\"Reverse Sear Meat\">Reverse-sear</a> a steak for better control over the interior temperature. Start by cooking the steak in the oven at about until it is almost done. Remove it from the oven and finish it by searing all sides on a really hot skillet. The heat from the skillet will finish cooking your steak, so take it out of the oven at the following temperatures depending on what level of doneness you prefer:<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you prefer rare steak, cook the meat until it’s right around .</li> \n    <li>For a medium steak, cook it to about .</li> \n    <li>To cook your steak well-done, bring it to about .</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cook a roast chicken or turkey breast-side down to keep the meat juicy. Simply place the meat upside down on a roasting rack and put it into the oven to cook. The juices and fat from the dark meat will drip down and saturate the white meat.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Meat Moist in the Oven Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-10.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>In general, each pound of poultry will take about 13 minutes to roast. So a 10-pound turkey would take about 2 hours and 10 minutes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep your brisket covered while it cooks to help it retain moisture. A lot of recipes recommend leaving the cover partially off while the brisket cooks, but that can cause this cut of meat to dry out by the time it’s ready to be served. Instead, leave the lid to the pot on, or cover the dish with aluminum foil while it roasts.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Meat Moist in the Oven Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-11.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cook the brisket on a low temperature, around to help it stay as moist as possible.</li> \n    <li>You can also slice the brisket into super thin pieces and put it back into the braising liquid for about 30 minutes before serving. This should help it absorb more moisture and flavor.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Monitor doneness with an instant-read thermometer. To use a meat thermometer, insert it into the thickest part of the meat and hold it in place until the temperature stops rising. It’s super important to make sure the meat is cooked enough so that it’s safe to eat, but it’s also important to not overcook it so it doesn’t get dry and tough.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Meat Moist in the Oven Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-12.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the cut has the bone in it, avoid letting the thermometer hit the bone.</li> \n    <li>Chicken needs to be cooked to , steak and pork need to be , and ground meat, like hamburger, needs to reach .</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let the meat rest when it comes out of the oven for 5-20 minutes. If you cut the meat too soon after it comes out of the oven, all those great juices are just going to flow out and turn the meat dry. Letting the meat rest allows those juices to get reabsorbed into the meat, helping it stay juicy and moist. Cover the meat with tented foil to keep it warm while it rests.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Meat Moist in the Oven Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-13.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A large roast should rest for about 20 minutes.</li> \n    <li>Chicken needs to rest for 10-20 minutes.</li> \n    <li>Steak and pork chops should rest for about 5 minutes.</li> \n    <li>Hamburger needs to rest for 4-6 minutes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep meat warm while it rests by tenting it in aluminum foil. Take a large piece of foil and fold it in half, then open it back up. Gently set it on top of the dish you made so that most of it is covered by the foil. The aluminum should help it retain its heat so it doesn’t get cold.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid actually wrapping the dish in foil. This could trap condensation as the dish cools and water down your dish.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Remember to wear oven mitts while handling hot pans, especially when you’re taking things in and out of the oven.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 13 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"7f3e49e1fb522c4a8a9497eda074f092","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn55@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-03-48-000_9b7ff3270a447300.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":57584,"destBytes":39694,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn55@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-03-48-000_9b7ff3270a447300.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-2.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn91@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-08-075_167a22951746e720.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-10.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn57@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-06-295_a073c1534c698bc7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-11.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn100@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-07-347_97871a376f039d5a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-12.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn20@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-08-187_0c8fd5935b5aee56.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-13.jpg/aid11903554-v4-728px-Keep-Meat-Moist-in-the-Oven-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn39@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-08-576_6cf685e4dadcdf3f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627574},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Make a Paper Garland","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Paper garlands can dress up your everyday space, decorate your home for the holidays, or make special occasions a bit more festive. The no-sew version is great for a simple craft with your kids, while the circular garlands look like professional decorations for birthdays and bridal showers. Try spending a fun afternoon creating your own garland to brighten up your space with a little DIY project. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: No-Sew Paper Garland\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"No-Sew-Paper-Garland\">No-Sew Paper Garland</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut strips from 2 pieces of paper. Pick out at least 2 pieces of construction paper in alternating colors. Using a pair of sharp scissors, cut out strips that are at least wide and about as long as the sheet of paper. You can adjust the size a bit according to your preference -- adjusting the width of the strips will make the garland loops wider and adjusting the length will make the loops longer.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try using red and pink pieces of paper for Valentine's Day, green and red paper for Christmas, or pastel colors for a baby shower.</li> \n    <li>Your strips don’t have to be the exact same size, so you can just eyeball it as you cut them out.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach the ends of one strip, then glue them together in a loop. Grab a strip of paper to start with and bring the ends together to form a closed circle. Overlap the ends about , then use a glue stick to attach them together. Hold the loop closed for about 1 minute to let the glue dry.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have a glue stick, use clear tape or a stapler instead.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Slide another strip through the first loop, then glue the ends together. Take another strip of paper and run it through the first loop until you connect the ends of that strip to form a second loop. Connect the ends of the second loop with the glue stick and hold them together for about 1 minute.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you're going for alternating colors, make sure you pick a different color for the second loop!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep adding loops until you run out of strips. Continue running each strip of paper through the previous loop and then connecting it to make a loop. Use your glue stick to secure each piece of paper so they all stay connected. If you'd like your garland to be a bit longer, just cut more strips of paper and create more loops until you're satisfied with the length.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Hang the garland with a nail or a push pin. You can drape the garland over a tree, a back patio, a column, or any piece of furniture. If you want to hang your garland up on the wall, hang the loops over a sturdy protruding nail or a pushpin on the wall.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Paper Garland Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These simple paper garlands make great decorations for the classroom, birthday parties, and even your own home!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Circular Paper Garland\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Circular-Paper-Garland\">Circular Paper Garland</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut cardstock into circles. Find a water bottle or the bottom of a glass and use that to stencil out circles that are about in diameter. Use scissors to cut them out to create your paper pieces.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cardstock is a little thicker than regular paper, so it will keep its shape better.</li> \n    <li>Try using patterned cardstock in alternating colors for a cool effect!</li> \n    <li>Or, go for some metallic cardstock to really catch the eye.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Arrange your circles in the order you’d like them to hang. On a flat surface, organize your circles so they’re in the order you want them to go. Start from the top and work your way down to create each strand.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Depending on how long you’d like your garland to be, you can use 5 to 20 circles for each strand.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sew down the center of one circle with a straight stitch. Place your first circle on your sewing machine and set your needle to a short straight stitch using white thread. Carefully sew directly down the middle of the circle, slowing down as you reach the end of the paper.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Although cardstock is thick, a normal sewing needle with regular strength thread should have no problem stitching right through it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pump the needle 10 times to create a length of thread after the circle. When you reach the end of the circle, use the knob on the side of your sewing machine to manually move the needle up and down 10 times. This will create a length of thread that’s floating after the initial circle.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Using the knob on the side gives you more control than the foot pedal, which is why you should use it for creating the extra length on the end.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Place the second circle down next, then keep stitching. Grab your next cardstock circle and place it directly behind the length of thread you just sewed. Stitch directly down the center of the next circle to connect it to the first one.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t get the stitches directly down the circle, that’s okay! Try to make them as centered as possible for an even strand.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add more circles until you’re happy with the length of your garland. Keep sewing circles and then stitching about 10 times in between each circle. When you’re finished with one strand, cut the thread and tie it off at the bottom to keep it in place.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Hang the garland with a push pin or double-sided tape. Place the top of your garland on a doorframe or a wall, then use a push pin or tape to hang it up. Add more strands right next to it for an interactive doorway or a fun picture wall at a party!<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Paper Garland Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try hanging up your garland strands in front of a white wall to make a fun background for people to take photos.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tissue Paper Garland\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tissue-Paper-Garland\">Tissue Paper Garland</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut 50 circles out of tissue paper. Grab a package of tissue paper and fold it into thirds. Use the bottom of a bowl or a cup to make circles in pencil, then use scissors to cut the circles out of each layer of tissue paper.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Folding the tissue paper will save you time so you don’t have to cut out each circle individually.</li> \n    <li>Try using multiple colors of tissue paper for a fun, decorative garland.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stack the circles in groups of 10. Group up the circles you cut out so they’re in 5 stacks of 10. If you’re using multiple colors of tissue paper, make each stack a different color or alternate the colors in each stack.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Paper Garland Step 14 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you wanted to make a purple gradient, try 2 stacks of dark purple, 2 stacks of light purple, and 1 stack of white.</li> \n    <li>Or, for a rainbow garland, alternate red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and purple in each stack.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Thread a needle with about of thread. Grab a sharp sewing needle and cut a length of sewing thread that’s long, or however long you’d like one strand to be. Put the thread through the eye of the needle, then tie a knot at the end of the thread that isn’t touching the needle.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use any color of sewing thread that you’d like to.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Push the needle through the center of 1 stack. Grab your first stack of tissue paper circles and line your needle up so it’s in the very center. Carefully push the needle through to the other side until it pushes through all 10 of the circles and through to the other side.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your needle is sharp enough, you shouldn’t have too much trouble pushing through the flimsy tissue paper.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Do the same thing to the rest of your stacks of paper. Grab the rest of your stacks and push the needle through their centers as well. Make sure you add the stacks in the order you’d like them to hang, since you can’t take them off again.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Spread out each individual circle so they’re about apart. Lay the length of thread down on a flat surface like a table or the floor. Slowly spread the circles out so that they overlap on the edges, but keep about of space in between the base of each circle.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This will make the tissue paper circles spread out over the length of the thread for a cute, fluffy decoration.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach the thread to each circle of paper with a dot of glue. Take a bottle of liquid school glue and align the tip of the glue with the hole that the thread pokes through the circle. Add a small dot of glue to the circle on top of the thread to hold the paper in place. Keep doing this to each circle, being careful not to get glue anywhere else.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This will hold the circles in their position on the thread so they don’t all fall to the bottom of the garland.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Tie the end of the thread in a double knot to secure the paper. Once you reach the end of your garland, take the needle off the thread and tie a small double knot in the end of it. Set your garland aside to dry for about 1 hour to make sure the circles are secure.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you hang the garland too early, the paper circles could fall off.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hang the garland up on a wall or a doorway. Grab the top of the garland and hold it up against the wall or the doorway. Use a push pin, a nail, or some double-sided tape to attach it to your area. Add more strands of the garland to completely cover a wall or doorway for a cute decoration.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-21-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Paper Garland Step 21 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-21-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try hanging your garland in front of a white backdrop to really make it pop.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Use alternating colors to really make your garland stand out.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Making a No-Sew Paper Garland\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-No-Sew-Paper-Garland\">Making a No-Sew Paper Garland</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Construction paper</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li> \n  <li>Glue, tape, or a stapler</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Trying a Circular Paper Garland\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Trying-a-Circular-Paper-Garland\">Trying a Circular Paper Garland</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>cardstock</li> \n  <li>Paper punch or scissors</li> \n  <li>Sewing machine</li> \n  <li>Thread</li> \n  <li>Thumbtacks</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Using Tissue Paper\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Tissue-Paper\">Using Tissue Paper</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Tissue paper</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li> \n  <li>Pencil</li> \n  <li>Sewing needle</li> \n  <li>Sewing thread</li> \n  <li>Liquid glue</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Garland-With-Scrap-Fabrics\" title=\"Make a Garland With Scrap Fabrics\">Make a Garland With Scrap Fabrics</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Paper-Garland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WKjJ9403S6g&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=34\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WKjJ9403S6g&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=34</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLyRMoIoSVg&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=42\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLyRMoIoSVg&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=42</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLyRMoIoSVg&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=49\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLyRMoIoSVg&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=49</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLyRMoIoSVg&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=68\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLyRMoIoSVg&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=68</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" \n   <li id=\"_note-16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-16\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DVZYAhwxtM&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=352\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DVZYAhwxtM&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=352</a></span> </li> \n   <li \n   <li id=\"_note-18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-18\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Zn84bYtwrs&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=130\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Zn84bYtwrs&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=130</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" \n   <li id=\"_note-20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Paper-Garland#_ref-20\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DVZYAhwxtM&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=528\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DVZYAhwxtM&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=528</a></span> </li> \n   <li
