\n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 12 Sep 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"fe5ba97c7c0af9f2db492ad30fa828bd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn38@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-03-48-056_e1b39f5ae3a2a2ac.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":34462,"destBytes":19356,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn38@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-03-48-056_e1b39f5ae3a2a2ac.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn49@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-06-141_645b87cf1ed9a5d8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-06-259_8a3eb4525527ecfb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid2558835-v4-728px-Make-a-Paper-Garland-Step-21-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn7@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-12-927_fba6a16301da48a3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627606},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Do Knee Ups","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>You might think of knee-ups or knee raises as a leg exercise, but they’re also a great workout for your hips, abs, and core! Sitting or standing knee-ups are simple exercises that you can do at home without any special equipment. For a more challenging exercise that will also work your upper body, try doing hanging knee-ups on a pull-up bar or gymnastics rings. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Standing Knee Ups\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Standing-Knee-Ups\">Standing Knee Ups</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Stand upright with your knees hip-width apart. Get into a comfortable standing position with your back straight and tall and your shoulders squared. Plant your feet so they’re slightly apart, and keep your knees lined up under your hips.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Knee Ups Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have trouble balancing, you can do this exercise while standing next to a chair or counter and rest your hand on it for support.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Brace your core muscles. Gently tense the muscles in your abdomen, sides, and lower back. Engaging these muscles will help you build strength in your core.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Knee-Ups-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Knee Ups Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To find your core muscles, imagine creating a firm band or belt of muscle around your lower body. You can also try pulling your belly button in towards your spine.</li> \n    <li>This exercise also helps strengthen your hips.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Raise one knee until your thigh is level with the floor. Breathe in deeply, then breathe out as you slowly raise one of your knees. Lift your leg until the back of your thigh is parallel with the floor.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep your back straight and tall as you lift your leg.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold for 1-2 seconds before returning to the start position. Pause for a second or 2 with your knee raised. Then, slowly and smoothly put your foot back on the floor while breathing out.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Switch to the other leg and repeat. After raising and lowering one knee, repeat the same process on the other side. Or, you can do several raises on one side, then switch to the other.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do 1-2 sets of 10-15 reps, either alternating knees or doing one side and then the other as separate sets.</li> \n    <li>To make the exercise more challenging, you can try doing more reps or adding small weights to your ankles.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Hanging Knee Ups\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hanging-Knee-Ups\">Hanging Knee Ups</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Grab a pull-up bar or gymnastics rings with an overhand grip. Hanging knee ups are also known as hanging knee raises. Stand under a bar or a set of gymnastics rings with your back straight and tall. Reach straight up with your palms facing forwards and grab the bar or rings from behind.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Knee-Ups-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Knee Ups Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your hands should be about shoulder-width apart.</li> \n    <li>In your starting position, your arms should be completely straight and your feet should be slightly off the floor.</li> \n    <li>This exercise is similar to a vertical knee raise, or “Captain’s Chair.” To do a vertical knee raise, instead of reaching up to grab a bar, you’d start by resting your forearms on a pair of parallel bars, as if they were the armrests on a chair.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pull your knees up toward your chest. Brace your core and tighten your abs. Try to use those muscles to lift your legs. Raise your knees up as far as you can, and try to touch your chest with the tops of your thighs.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep your body as still as you can, and try to keep the motion of your legs slow and smooth. Don’t let your body swing from side to side or twist around.</li> \n    <li>If you have trouble lifting your legs high enough to touch your chest, aim to raise your knees until your thighs are parallel to the floor.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lower your legs in a slow, controlled motion. Once you reach the top of the knee-up, slowly and carefully return to your starting position. Don’t let your legs suddenly drop, and try not to do any fast or jerky movements.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Slow, controlled movements will make the exercise more effective.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Aim for 3 sets of 10 reps. This is an exercise that takes a lot of strength, so don’t worry if you can’t do a ton of reps right away. 3 sets of 10 reps is a good general goal to aim for when you’re doing any strength-building exercise.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> If you can’t manage that, start with a smaller number, like 2 sets of 5 reps.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is a great exercise for your lower abs, but you’ll also build strength in your hips, arms, shoulders, and upper back.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Sitting Knee Ups\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sitting-Knee-Ups\">Sitting Knee Ups</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Sit on the edge of a chair or bench. Find a chair or workout bench and sit tall, with your back straight. Put your feet flat on the floor in front of you.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Knee-Ups-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Knee Ups Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re sitting on a chair with a back, sit far enough forward so that you can tilt your body back in the chair.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lean back so you’re partially reclining and grab the sides of the chair. Slowly tilt back on your buttocks until your body is leaning at a 45° angle. Hold onto the sides of the chair to keep you from falling backwards.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Knee-Ups-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Knee Ups Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re on a bench, you can also stabilize yourself by reaching back and resting your hands on the bench behind you.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lift both knees toward your chest. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Abs-Tight-when-Working-Out\" title=\"Keep Abs Tight when Working Out\">Brace your abdominal muscles</a> and slowly pull your knees up toward your chest. Keep your back straight and only move your lower body (legs and hips).<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep your core engaged as you raise your legs. Don’t allow your upper body to rock back as your legs come up.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lower your legs slowly back to the starting position. Once you’ve pulled your legs up as far as they can comfortably go, lower them back toward the floor in a slow, controlled motion. Ideally, they shouldn’t quite touch the ground before you start lifting them back up again.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your abs will get a better workout if you don’t let your feet touch the floor between lifts. However, it’s okay to touch the floor if you find it too difficult to keep your feet up.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Repeat this exercise 10-15 times. Keep raising and lowering your knees several more times—aim for about 10-15. If you like, you can rest for a few minutes, then do another set. With practice, you will eventually be able to complete more repetitions.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This exercise is great for toning your abs, especially if you keep them engaged and tight throughout the whole workout.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup> It will also help strengthen your lower back, hips, and glutes.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Exercises that involve raising your knees while supporting yourself with your upper body, such as hanging knee-ups or the similar “Captain’s Chair” maneuver, are great for building the rectus abdominis, or 6-pack muscles. They’re also good for working your hip flexors.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Knee ups help strengthen the muscles in your core that control spinal flexion, or the movements of your torso that help you do basic things like sitting up from a lying position or bending over to pick something up. Strengthening these muscles can help stabilize your spine and reduce lower back pain.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you have any injuries to your knees or back, talk to your doctor before trying these exercises. It’s a good idea to get medical advice before starting any new exercise program, especially if you have any serious health concerns.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Knee-Ups&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.msn.com/en-us/health/exercise/strength/knee-raises/ss-BBtOf0P\">https://www.msn.com/en-us/health/exercise/strength/knee-raises/ss-BBtOf0P</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" \n   <li id=\"_note-17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-17\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" \n   <li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.building-muscle101.com/knee-up-exercise-for-abs/\">https://www.building-muscle101.com/knee-up-exercise-for-abs/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-20\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://heartfitforlife.org/cardia/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Core-Training-Part-2-.pdf\">http://heartfitforlife.org/cardia/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Core-Training-Part-2-.pdf</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-21\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.building-muscle101.com/knee-up-exercise-for-abs/\">https://www.building-muscle101.com/knee-up-exercise-for-abs/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-22\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.acefitness.org/getfit/studies/bestworstabexercises.pdf\">https://www.acefitness.org/getfit/studies/bestworstabexercises.pdf</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Knee-Ups#_ref-23\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.spine-health.com/glossary/flexion\">https://www.spine-health.com/glossary/flexion</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Sep 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"9c60951e9ab19ad3ab1e4dfd11b59417","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn16@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-03-51-094_f39f263568118bc5.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":78258,"destBytes":52680,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn16@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-03-51-094_f39f263568118bc5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-12-255_fdacf669c9d2f65b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn12@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-07-312_d0225acf48a7a799.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn32@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-08-962_5a0789c6f8dbb1bf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Do-Knee-Ups-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid11988850-v4-728px-Do-Knee-Ups-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn68@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-13-467_b03bbbbef4f402e5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627618},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Polish Scratches Out of Aluminum","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Aluminum is used to make all kinds of everyday items from cars and wheels to refrigerators and kitchenware. It can be polished to make it very shiny, even mirror-like, and is a cheaper alternative to stainless steel and chrome. If you want to get scratches out of something like an aluminum refrigerator, oven, cup, car wheel, bike part, chair, or any other piece of aluminum, try polishing them out. As long as the aluminum doesn’t have any super deep gouges and dents, you can polish out the scuffs and scratches with a few basic supplies and some elbow grease! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Removing Light Scuffs with a Scouring Pad\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Removing-Light-Scuffs-with-a-Scouring-Pad\">Removing Light Scuffs with a Scouring Pad</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mask off any non-metal areas around the scratched aluminum using tape. Use strips of blue painter’s tape or masking tape. Cover up any sensitive or delicate parts of the aluminum object that you don’t want to accidentally scratch or get polishing compound on during the polishing process.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Polish Scratches Out of Aluminum Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11755134-v4-728px-Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you want to polish scuffs out of something like an aluminum stove or fridge, you might want to mask off things like control panels if they are near the scratched area.</li> \n    <li>This method works for very minor scuffs and scratches. Keep in mind that you won’t be able to get the aluminum looking like it is straight out of the factory, but you will be able to hide the scuffs and shine up the metal.</li> \n    <li>You’ll get the best results using this method if you polish the entire aluminum surface, not just the scuffed area, so that the finish looks uniformly shiny when you’re done. However, if the scuffed area isn’t too conspicuous, such as in a corner of an aluminum stove door, you can just polish the scuff marks out and blend it in to the surrounding metal as much as possible.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rub a scouring pad back and forth over the scuffed area, going with the grain. Hold a scouring pad in your hand and press it gently against the scratched area of the aluminum. Rub it back and forth over the area using slow controlled motions until the scuff marks disappear and the metal starts to look shiny.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Most aluminum has a unidirectional grain, which are actually brush marks caused by the original polishing process that the aluminum went through. Never rub the scouring pad across this grain or you might end up making the scuffs worse.</li> \n    <li>If the aluminum item you want to polish doesn’t have a visible grain, just pick a direction to rub the scouring pad in and only move it back and forth in this direction. Don’t change directions or move it in circular motions or you might just create more scuff marks.</li> \n    <li>Scouring pads are also known as buffing pads. The finer the git, the better for this job. You can get a fine-grit scouring pad at an auto detail supply shop.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply metal polish to the aluminum using a microfiber cloth. Squeeze a small drop of metal polish onto a microfiber cloth. Scrub the metal polish into the affected area and the surrounding aluminum surfaces using back and forth motions and going with the grain of the aluminum.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> Keep rubbing until the polish disappears into the metal and the surface looks nice and shiny.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use a special aluminum polish or any type of metal polish you have available. Both will work to shine up the surface.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a microfiber cloth to apply metal wax or sealant to the aluminum. Wrap a microfiber cloth around your index finger and dip it into a container of metal wax or sealant. Rub it over the aluminum surface using even strokes in alternating directions until the wax or sealant gets absorbed and there are no streaks on the metal.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This will seal the aluminum and protect it from oxidation.</li> \n    <li>You can get metal waxes and sealants at an auto detail supply shop.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove any tape that you applied to mask off certain areas. Peel up the masking tape or blue painter’s tape. Dispose of it in your recycling bin.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> <br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Sanding out Deep Scratches\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sanding-out-Deep-Scratches\">Sanding out Deep Scratches</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Spray WD-40 all over the aluminum you want to polish to lubricate it. Cover the scratched aluminum surface evenly in WD-40. This lubrication will help carry away the metal particles that you remove during sanding.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This method is known as wet sanding. You can do it with water too, but WD-40 is the best lubricant when you are sanding bare metal.</li> \n    <li>You can use this method to sand and polish out curb damage on an aluminum car wheel or bicycle crank shaft, for example.</li> \n    <li>Since you’ll be actually removing a layer of metal using this method, the final results will look best if you sand and polish the entire aluminum object, not just the scratched part. For instance, if you want to polish scratches out of the face of an aluminum wheel, sand the entire wheel down.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sand out the scratches using 220-grit sandpaper. Attach 220-grit sandpaper to a sanding block, an electrical sander, or just use it in your hand if the scratched area is small. Press the sandpaper firmly against the scratched area and move it back and forth over the scratches in alternating directions until they disappear.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep in mind that if there are very deep dents and gouges in the aluminum, you won’t be able to polish them out completely by sanding. However, you can at least make them less visible and restore shine to the surrounding surface.</li> \n    <li>Make sure that the sandpaper you used is labelled as safe for wet sanding. Most fine-grit sandpaper is OK to use for wet sanding, but double-check the packaging or the back of the paper to be sure.</li> \n    <li>Wear safety glasses and a dust mask when you sand metal, especially if you are using a powerful electric sander.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Switch to 1500-grit sandpaper and sand the aluminum to smooth it out. Move the sandpaper back and forth in alternating directions, applying firm pressure, all over the same area you just sanded the deep scratches out of. This will get rid of the small scuffs and scratches made by the coarser sandpaper to smooth out the surface and start shining it up.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have exactly 1500-grit sandpaper, it’s fine to use another very fine-grit sandpaper. Anywhere between 1000-grit and 2000-grit is fine for this step.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Give the aluminum a final sanding with 3000-grit sandpaper. Switch to 3000-grit sandpaper and go back over the entire surface you have been sanding. This will make the aluminum very shiny.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t want a super-shiny, mirror-like finish, you can use sandpaper that is slightly less than 3000-grit to finish sanding. For example, something between 2000-grit and 2500-grit.</li> \n    <li>If there is no more WD-40 left on the aluminum by this stage, spray a little directly onto the sandpaper to lubricate it for this last round of sanding. This will help make the aluminum extra-shiny and carry away fine metal particles so they don’t stick to the surface.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rub aluminum polish onto the surface using a polishing pad or cloth. Put some aluminum polish onto a clean area of a polishing pad or polishing cloth. Work the polish into the aluminum using circular motions, starting in the center and working your way out to the edges.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll know the polish is doing its job when the polishing cloth or pad starts to get black. If you don’t see this black residue on your cloth or pad, rub harder and keep working the polish in all over the surface until you do.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Buff the polish off with a clean, soft cloth. Rub a clean, soft cloth, such as a microfiber cloth, vigorously all over the polished surface using circular and alternating back and forth motions. Keep buffing the aluminum until it is uniformly shiny and there are no traces of polish left on the surface.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can keep buffing the aluminum until you achieve the level of <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Polished-Aluminum-Shiny\" title=\"Keep Polished Aluminum Shiny\">shine</a> you want. However, once there are no streaks or other residue from the polish left on the surface, feel free to stop.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don't polish aluminum that has any type of special coating, such as a Teflon coating, or you will just end up damaging the coating. You can only polish scratches out of bare aluminum.</li> \n  <li>Don't use sandpaper that is any coarser than 220-grit on aluminum or you will just make more deep scratches in the surface.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Removing Light Scuffs with a Scouring Pad\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Removing-Light-Scuffs-with-a-Scouring-Pad_2\">Removing Light Scuffs with a Scouring Pad</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Scouring pad</li> \n  <li>Metal polish</li> \n  <li>Microfiber cloth</li> \n  <li>Metal wax or sealant</li> \n  <li>Masking tape or painter’s tape (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Sanding Out Deep Scratches\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sanding-Out-Deep-Scratches_2\">Sanding Out Deep Scratches</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>WD-40</li> \n  <li>220-grit sandpaper</li> \n  <li>1500-grit sandpaper</li> \n  <li>3000-grit sandpaper</li> \n  <li>Electric sander or sanding block (optional)</li> \n  <li>Aluminum polish</li> \n  <li>Microfiber cloth</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 11 Sep 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11755134-v4-728px-Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"9130e2a97c453be04fd14719f30c6817","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn18@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-03-48-023_2f3eda4b52531d96.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":46986,"destBytes":27480,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11755134-v4-728px-Polish-Scratches-Out-of-Aluminum-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn18@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-03-48-023_2f3eda4b52531d96.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627606},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Create a Gradient in Google Slides","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>When making a slideshow presentation on Google Slides, many people make their backgrounds and textboxes a single solid color. However, creating and using gradients on Google Slides can make your presentation stand out.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Applying a Gradient\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Applying-a-Gradient\">Applying a Gradient</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Go to <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external text\" href=\"https://docs.google.com/presentation/\">docs.google.com/presentation/</a> to create or access a slideshow. If asked, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Log-in-to-Google\" title=\"Log in to Google\">log in</a> by entering your email and password and pressing .<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Open an existing presentation you want to edit, or click  to start a new one.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-2.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Choose your theme. To change the theme of your presentation, click  from the menu bar at the top of the screen.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-3.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Though this isn't mandatory, choosing a theme other than \"Simple Light\" and \"Simple Dark\" will give you more color options for making your gradient. Themes come with assigned colors used throughout them, and when making a gradient, you can use the theme colors to match the rest of your slideshow.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Click . This opens up the option to either add an image to or change the color of your background.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-4.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"545\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Select the colored circle across from . A drop-down menu will appear, automatically selected in the \"Solid\" option (unless the theme you chose already had a gradient demo background). The \"Solid\" page will give you an idea as to what colors you can use for your gradient.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-5.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"545\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Go to the \"Gradient\" page. Click  next to the pre-selected  button at the top of the drop-down menu. This takes you to a page with several multicolored and ombre boxes. You can select these to be the background of your presentation.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-6.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Open the custom gradient menu. It shouldn't matter whether you click  or the plus sign underneath it - you should be taken to the same page. A menu will open at the middle of the screen with several options: ,  (if on the linear option) or  (if on the radial option), , and , along with a color bar at the bottom.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-7.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Decide whether you'd like your presentation to have a linear or radial gradient. A linear gradient will appear ombre and have colors fade into each other in a straight line. The radial option will have a circle or fractions of a circle, with colors fading into and away from the arc.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-8.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Experiment with different angles and points of center.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-9.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you choose to make a linear gradient, there are several angle options to choose from, ranging from 0° to 315°. 90° is the default option, with colors starting from the top and fading down. Different angles will have different fading sequences (some will be up and down, some side to side, and some diagonal).</li>\n<li>If you choose the radial option, you will be given options for where the point of center of your gradient will be. You can choose the circle/arc to appear in the middle, top left corner, top right corner, bottom left corner, or bottom right corner. Try different points to see how the colors blend.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Choose your first two colors. Go to the color bar at the bottom of the menu. Select the end box on either the left or right, and then click the colored circle next to  under  to choose a color.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-10.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can make a custom color to use, choose a color from the menu, or use a theme color. Repeat with the box on the other end of the color bar.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Adding More Customizations\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Adding-More-Customizations\">Adding More Customizations</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Consider using transparency. You can make part of your gradient transparent or translucent.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-11.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>To make one of your colors the transparent option, click the colored circle to open the color menu. Select  at the top of the color menu, located next to a drop with a slash over it to signify the transparent option.</li>\n<li>To make a color translucent, first, choose the color you are using in its opaque form. Then, reopen the color menu if needed, and select the  option. Click and drag your mouse along the checkered sidebar. This adjusts how \"see-through\" the color is.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add gradient stops. Gradient stops allow you to add more colors to your gradient. Once you have your two base colors, click . The color menu will reopen, and selecting a color will add it to your gradient. To move where the color is located in the gradient, go to the color bar at the bottom. Adding a gradient stop will add a small colored circle near the middle of the color bar. Use your mouse to drag the circle along the color bar to move where the color is located in the gradient.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-12.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>To add more colors, add more gradient stops with different colors.</li>\n<li>You can also remove gradient stops by selecting the circle of the color you would like to remove and selecting  under the  option.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Make gradients using the \"theme colors\". Selecting a theme for your slideshow will add different colors to the color menu. To stay consistent throughout the presentation, you can make gradients using the theme colors and match the text.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-13.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Use gradients in different ways. Gradients don't only apply to the background of a Google Slides presentation - you can make words, textboxes, and shapes gradient, too! Create \"Word Art\" and change the background from a solid color to a gradient color sequence. Shapes and textboxes can be changed from their transparent and solid grey demo backgrounds to other colors and gradients. Experiment with different styles and ways to incorporate gradients into your presentation.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create a Gradient in Google Slides Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-14.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"01929149777e9053e934024c99aa4a75","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn29@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-03-48-044_89caba9f51dd229d.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":41431,"destBytes":21514,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn29@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-03-48-044_89caba9f51dd229d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-2.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn24@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-08-349_a8150abd5395c0bd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-3.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn29@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-06-308_cb4283ddf5035922.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-4.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn32@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-13-374_c9188909736e7471.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-5.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn5@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-06-220_6b118db0a0e1e529.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-6.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-11-730_0a027254b3048cc5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-7.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn51@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-08-555_606c801679b8a723.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-8.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn72@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-12-092_741ba4ebdd9e5b14.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-9.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn87@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-08-633_07b44d0e6e5c9703.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-10.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn96@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-07-197_904ab9317fe963ef.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-11.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn30@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-07-490_2bc2bade564c3ea6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-12.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn63@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-10-372_8f793b40d75ddcfc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-13.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn19@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-13-071_8b4b0d268f1c70a7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-14.jpg/aid11115309-v4-728px-Create-a-Gradient-in-Google-Slides-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn67@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-08-597_83c4e435e8502229.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627609},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Use a Ceramic Cooktop","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>A ceramic, or glass cooktop, allows you to cook food on a completely flat surface. This type of cooking area is pretty straightforward to use, and is easy to clean and maintain. If you keep a few important precautions in mind, you’ll be able to keep your appliance in tip-top condition for years to come! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Selecting the Best Cookware\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Selecting-the-Best-Cookware\">Selecting the Best Cookware</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose pots and pans that fit the size of the cooking area. Measure across each of your cooking zones, or burners, to see how wide they are. Keep in mind that ceramic cooktops heat up beneath the surface, and focus heat within these circular areas. Then, measure the bottom of the pots and pans that you use the most. Ideally, aim to use cookware that fits evenly in the cooking zones so the heat can spread consistently.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if 1 of your cooking zones is wide, you’d want to use a pan that’s about wide.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pick out stainless steel cookware for your cooktop. Check the labeling on your pots and pans to see what they’re made of. Try to use cookware made with stainless steel, as opposed to stoneware, cast iron, ceramic, or glass. Stainless steel heats up very consistently, which makes it a great candidate for your pots and pans. Other metals, like cast iron, tend to scratch and scuff the ceramic surface.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-2.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have stainless steel cookware on hand, heavy-weight aluminum is also a great solution.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Opt for cookware that’s more flat than rounded. Flip over your pots and pans and see how curved they are along the bottom. Since ceramic stove tops are completely flat, curved cookware may not heat up as evenly as flatter pots and pans.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-3.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Ideally, the bottom of the pan of pot should be snug against the entire cooking zone.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Select wood or metal cooking tools instead of plastic ones. Pick out utensils that aren’t as likely to melt on a hot cooking surface. If you have a lot of plastic spatulas, it may be worthwhile to invest in a few wooden or metal spoons, which will last longer.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-4.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, use a wooden spoon instead of a plastic spatula when working with a ceramic cooktop.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clean any food gunk off the bottom of your pans before using them. Wash your dishes thoroughly after they’ve sat on the cooktop for awhile. It can be easy for old crumbs and gunk to build up on the bottom of your cookware, which can leave scuffs and scratches on your cooktop. Before using them, double-check that the bottom of your pots and pans are as smooth as possible, which will save you time in the long run.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-5.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Operating the Cooktop\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Operating-the-Cooktop\">Operating the Cooktop</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Turn the designated knobs to get your cooktop heated up. Look around your cooktop for specific knobs that control the temperature of your cooking zones. Keep in mind that these knobs may be behind the cooktop, or alongside of it. For specific guidance, consult your user manual for in-depth instructions.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-6.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Lift up your pots and pans instead of sliding them along the cooktop. Avoid the temptation to slide your cookware to another cooking zone, even if you’re in a rush. Keep in mind that ceramic can scratch easily, especially if you’re sliding your pots and pans across. Instead, make a conscious effort to lift and lower your dishes when you move them around.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-7.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Check the light indicator to see if the cooktop is hot. Keep an eye out for an LED light indicator somewhere on your cooktop. Generally, this light will be illuminated when the cooktop is warm or hot to the touch. Whenever you see this light, do your best not to touch the cooktop, or else you may burn yourself.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-8.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Read through your ceramic cooktop’s user manual for specific instructions and safety precautions.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Cleaning Your Cooktop\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cleaning-Your-Cooktop\">Cleaning Your Cooktop</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wait for the cooktop to cool down completely before cleaning it. Check your cooktop’s user manual to see how to turn your appliance on and off. Most cooktops have some kind of indicator to let you know when the stovetop is still hot, which can prevent you from burning yourself. If you apply cleaner while the stovetop is still hot, you may do long-term damage to the ceramic surface.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-9.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Hold your hand above the stovetop to see if it feels warm or not.</li> \n    <li>Ideally, try to clean off your cooktop whenever it looks messy. For instance, you don’t need to clean off the cooktop if you’re simply boiling a kettle of water.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Brush any obvious crumbs off the stovetop. Grab a sharp scraper and hold it at a 45-degree angle along the edge of your ceramic cooktop. Drag the scraper across the surface of the stovetop, applying a consistent, moderate amount of pressure as you go. At this point, take a clean paper towel or rag and wipe any obvious messes off the stovetop. This will make the cooktop easier to clean, and will help you focus on more stubborn stains.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-10.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t use a dull or damaged scraper for this, or you may end up scratching the cooktop.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wipe down the cooktop with a specialized cleaner and a paper towel. Spritz the surface of your ceramic cooktop with a cleaning product designed for ceramic surfaces. Rub the cleaner into the stovetop with a rag or paper towel to clean off the entire surface.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup> Don’t apply too much pressure as you clean, or else you may cause the ceramic surface to fracture.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-11.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>With cleaners, a little can go a long way! Start with a few drops, and add more cleaner if you need it.</li> \n    <li>You can find specialty cleaner online, or at certain stores that sell cleaning supplies.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spritz over the cooktop with water and wipe it off. Fill an empty spray bottle with water and coat the ceramic surface in a light mist. Take a clean paper towel or rag and go over the cooktop one more time to wipe away any excess cleaner.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use a Ceramic Cooktop Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-12.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Lukewarm water is fine for this.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Soak up spills as soon as they happen—if they get stuck to the ceramic surface, you may end up damaging the glass if you try to clean it off later.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Only use cleaners that are specifically designed for ceramic or glass cooktops. Despite the name, traditional glass cleaners aren’t a good cleaning solution for your cooktop, since they tend to have some harsh chemicals in them.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Avoid using abrasive cleaning pads on your cooktop.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Cleaning Your Cooktop\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cleaning-Your-Cooktop_2\">Cleaning Your Cooktop</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Scraper blade</li> \n  <li>Paper towel</li> \n  <li>Cloth</li> \n  <li>Ceramic glass cleaner</li> \n  <li>Water</li> \n  <li>Spray bottle</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.us.schott.com/innovation/works-electric-cooktop/\">https://www.us.schott.com/innovation/works-electric-cooktop/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\"
