+0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"8d6c1d5985a4f76e6cdc4c2f19796627","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn5@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-03-48-285_d8c1bf77d34eb2d9.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":70716,"destBytes":43820,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn5@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-03-48-285_d8c1bf77d34eb2d9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-2.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn25@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-06-172_f3cd4ff037718b18.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-3.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn52@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-11-852_8ee134c86f470e6f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-4.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn11@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-13-141_d92561566e88de20.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-5.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn11@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-11-246_da901228ea1e6a4b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-6.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn52@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-12-728_df5dc550d31e22bc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-7.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn84@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-10-398_5219220bc23a9837.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-8.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn20@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-09-915_f4f2d21cf186d204.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-9.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn76@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-08-516_d13cc19280deb32d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-10.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn3@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-10-622_be085b2efca4adda.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-11.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn84@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-12-889_fb59a2a2325b59b3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-12.jpg/aid12025975-v4-728px-Use-a-Ceramic-Cooktop-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn46@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-06-885_a4d683fa026ff75e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627635},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Dust is an unfortunate part of life, and finding dust bunnies under the bed can be seriously gross. Fortunately, you don’t have to let dust rule your life. By taking a few precautions and cleaning your bedroom once a week, you can deter dust from accumulating under the bed and make your cleaning ritual that much easier. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Dust-Proofing Your Bedroom\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Dust-Proofing-Your-Bedroom\">Dust-Proofing Your Bedroom</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Keep your floor clear of clutter. Stuffed animals, clothes, rugs, and other soft objects can collect dust and transfer it to the floor under your bed. Try to keep your floor clear as much as you can to remove the threat of dust and keep your floor clean.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 01.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try putting a laundry hamper in your room to collect your dirty clothes throughout the week.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put shoes away in your closet. Shoes track dust, dirt, and other allergens into the room that can accumulate under your bed. Take your shoes off before you go into your bedroom and put them away in your closet or mudroom as soon as you get home.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-02.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 02.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-02.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-02.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Taking your shoes off before you come inside will also help avoid tracking dirt or mud into the rest of your house.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach a bed skirt to your bed to deter dust. Bed skirts are long sheets that fit around the lower part of your bed frame and touch the top of the floor. They provide a barrier to discourage dust from collecting underneath the bed, making it easier for you to clean up the dust that does accumulate. Put one of these on your bed to keep the dust out as it collects in your room.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-03.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 03.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-03.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-03.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure you wash your bed skirt every week along with your other bedding.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Install an air filter on your furnace and air conditioning unit. Air filters can help collect dust before it reaches your room, making it easier to keep out from underneath your bed. Put a certified allergy and asthma friendly filter on your furnace and air conditioner to collect dust before it can circulate around your home.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-04.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 04.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-04.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-04.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid filters that use heat or electrostatic, as those can make dust worse.</li> \n    <li>You can also buy a free-standing air filter to place in the room without hooking it up to a furnace or air conditioner.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Air out your room as often as possible. Whenever you can, open up the doors and windows in your bedrooms to let the air circulate. This will discourage dust from accumulating under your bed, and it can freshen up your home as well!<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-05.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 05.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-05.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-05.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Consider putting bug screens on your windows if you’re going to be keeping them open for a long time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a fan to circulate the air. Set up a box or standing fan in your room and keep it on low to move the air around in your room. This can also help keep your room cool in the summer months and leave your room smelling fresh.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-06.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 06.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-06.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-06.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have a ceiling fan, you can turn that on instead.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Cleaning and Dusting the Room\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cleaning-and-Dusting-the-Room\">Cleaning and Dusting the Room</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Dust the room with a wet rag once a week. Run a rag under warm water and wring out the excess. Dust any flat surfaces in your room with the wet rag to get rid of the dust before it has the chance to migrate under your bed. If you have allergies, wear a dust mask as you clean to avoid irritating your sinuses.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-07.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 07.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-07.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-07.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A wet rag will pick up the dust much better than a dry one.</li> \n    <li>If you have hardwood floors, put the wet rag on the ground and push it under the bed with a broom handle.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wash your bedding once a week. Your sheets, pillowcases, and comforters all collect a lot of dust throughout the week and can transfer it under your bed. Try to wash your bedding at least once a week in water that's , or at least change your sheets and pillowcases every week.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-08.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 08.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-08.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-08.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your pet sleeps in their own bed in your room, wash their bedding once a week as well.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Vacuum your carpet or rugs once a week. If you have rugs or carpet in your room, run a vacuum over them at least once a week. Make sure your vacuum has a high-quality dust filter on it so it can collect and trap all of the dust particles from your room.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-09.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 09.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-09.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-09.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Carpets and rugs are huge dust collectors. If you have the option, try to leave your floor bare so dust can’t stick to it.</li> \n    <li>If you have any plush furniture in your bedroom, you can also use your vacuum on that once a week.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clean your curtains or blinds once a week. If you have curtains in your room, take them down and wash them in water that’s at least . If you have blinds, use a damp cloth to wipe them down once a week and get rid of the dust.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-10.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have the option, consider putting in roller shades to deter dust.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wash your rugs with hot water once a week. Throw your rugs in a hot water wash cycle that’s at least . This will kill the dust mites in the rug, leaving it dust and allergen-free.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Keep Dust from Collecting Under Your Bed Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-11.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To keep your room even more dust-free, try not using rugs at all so dust can’t accumulate.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Removing the clutter from your room is the best way to keep dust out from under your bed.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you have a dust mite allergy, wear a dust-filtering mask when you vacuum or dust your room.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg","linkMd5":"8a57d0ef7d14f271181b5a8c62f2ca24","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn40@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-03-281_4924502522f2a5f2.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":28843,"destBytes":14248,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-01.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn40@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-03-281_4924502522f2a5f2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-02.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-02.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn63@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-09-664_616ea138c9a04afe.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-03.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-03.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn23@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-10-766_20a3ce9d8da81f17.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-04.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-04.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn67@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-07-131_efb9711ddf2be7a2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-05.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-05.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn62@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-06-207_8823597851022a29.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-06.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-06.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn64@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-12-713_48bfefec30d5c133.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-07.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-07.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn31@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-06-375_57bf1820f3d255ae.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-08.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-08.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-11-227_1a817279975dc736.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-09.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-09.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn44@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-09-984_bf452ecbd8894c63.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-10.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn84@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-07-216_d116d9a76b7dcb6e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-11.jpg/aid12036454-v4-728px-Keep-Dust-from-Collecting-Under-Your-Bed-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn16@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-13-164_d19659f7d7a71af0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627635},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Practice Color Theory","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Whether you’re a graphic designer or a visual artist, you have to work with a variety of colors on a daily basis. Color theory helps you to pinpoint the various emotions and attitudes that different hues and color combinations convey. To practice and integrate color theory into your latest art projects, choose a variety of hues or color schemes to communicate a certain message. If you’d like to cater to a specific emotion or mindset, use both color theory and color psychology to figure out which feelings are associated with different colors. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Practice-Color-Theory&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Practice-Color-Theory&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Choosing Hues and Color Schemes for a Project\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Choosing-Hues-and-Color-Schemes-for-a-Project\">Choosing Hues and Color Schemes for a Project</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Create basic color schemes with primary and secondary colors. Take a look at your color palette before starting on a new creative project. Red, yellow, and blue are primary colors, which work together to create secondary colors like orange, green, and purple. As you embark on new colorful projects, review these different color mixtures, and how each hue connects with other shades.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>“Hue” is another term for a generic color.</li> \n    <li>Look at a color wheel to see how different hues bleed and connect with one another.</li> \n    <li>To review, red and yellow form orange; yellow and blue form green; and blue and red form purple.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use the additive color mixing model to create digital color schemes. Imagine 3 separate red, blue, and green spotlights intersecting in a large Venn diagram, forming smaller slivers of yellow, cyan, magenta, and a white center portion. Remember that different colors can be formed when different shades of light combine. Since the additive color mixing model focuses on how colors of light are viewed by the eye, try applying it to a potential logo, or other types of professional, digital publications.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-2.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The additive color mixing model focuses on how the human eye perceives color.</li> \n    <li>Use an online mixture tool to see how different colors appear on screen with the additive color mixing model: <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://micro.magnet.fsu.edu/primer/java/scienceopticsu/primarycolors/additiveprimaries\">https://micro.magnet.fsu.edu/primer/java/scienceopticsu/primarycolors/additiveprimaries</a>.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Implement the subtractive color mixing model in your print publications. The subtractive color mixing model combines the wavelengths of different colors to create new shades. To better understand this model, imagine a Venn diagram of 3 separate cyan, magenta, and yellow circles. Envision slivers of blue forming between cyan and magenta, green forming between cyan and yellow, and red forming between magenta and yellow. Note that, when combined, cyan, magenta, and yellow form black.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-3.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This model is used by color printers, and helps the human eye process color on printed material.</li> \n    <li>Different colors have different light wavelengths, which cancel one another out in this model. For instance, red has a long wavelength, green has a medium wavelength, and blue has a short wavelength.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Go with warm tones like reds, oranges, and yellows to create bright color schemes. Associate warm colors with bright, sunny hues. On the color wheel, remember that red, red-orange, orange, orange-yellow, yellow, and yellow-green are all on the warm spectrum since they’re sunny, fiery tones. Note that warm tones have longer color wavelengths, with red being the longest and yellow-green being the shortest. <sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-4.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Warm tones are often associated with sunsets, campfires, and other bright color combinations.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Choose cool tones like greens, blues, and purples to make a color scheme. Connect cool colors with darker, more subtle hues. As you examine the color wheel, place green, green-blue, blue, indigo, blue-purple, and purple on the cool color spectrum, as opposed to the warm spectrum. Create reflective and soothing color schemes by combining different varieties of these colors. As you factor in the additive and subtractive color models, note that cool colors have shorter wavelengths, with green being the longest and purple being the shortest.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-5.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Play around with tone, tint, and shade to create new colors. When designing a color palette for a new project, try tweaking different hues to make them lighter or darker. To “tint” a shade, mix white into the original hue. If you’d prefer to create a darker color, use black to add “shade.” If you’re looking for some kind of middle ground, incorporate a splash of gray to a hue to add “tone.” Use different variations of both primary and secondary colors to create new shades.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-6.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, robin’s egg blue is a tinted alteration of a generic blue hue. On the other hand, navy blue is a shaded variation.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Create a synchronized color scheme with analogous colors. If you’re trying to create a subtle, stylish backdrop for piece of art or an interior design, try using different color variations of the same hue. Add white, black, or gray to a color to modify the hue, then combine different variations to create a fun color scheme. Experiment with both light and dark versions of different colors, whether you’re working on an art project, a graphic design publication, or an interior renovation.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-7.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if you’re trying to paint a sky backdrop for a piece of art, try using an analogous blue color scheme. Use darker blues for the base of the sky, then blend into lighter shades of blue.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make your project pop with complementary colors. Look at a color wheel to find hues that are opposite of one another on the color wheel, like red and green. These opposing hues emphasize one another with their differing color values. Keep in mind that complementary colors don’t have to be generic hues—tinted and shaded colors also have respective opposites on the color wheel, as well.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-8.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, try making a more engaging logo by including 2 complementary colors in your brand’s identity. If you’re running an ocean-themed jewelry store, try mixing light blue and peach to design an effective, eye-popping logo.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Develop a dynamic color scheme with triadic colors. Choose 3 colors that are an equal distance away from one another on the color wheel to create a triadic color scheme. If you’d like to add more depth to an aspect of your design or art project, use triadic colors to provide harmony and emphasis without the direct contrast of complementary colors. To find a triadic color scheme, place an equilateral triangle on top of a color wheel, and use all 3 colors that the triangle points to.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-9.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, purple, orange, and green are equally separated from each other, which forms a color triad.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Practice-Color-Theory&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Communicating Messages with Color\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Communicating-Messages-with-Color\">Communicating Messages with Color</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Associate different blues with a feeling of security. Incorporate shades of blue into your art and design projects to give off a calming and secure vibe. While color alone can’t completely define the mood of a design or piece of art, you can use it to set an emotionally-driven stage for your project. Use blue to establish a comfortable, relatable environment for potential viewers, so these people are more inclined to engage with your work.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-10.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>In some high-risk areas, blue lights are successfully used to prevent suicide attempts.</li> \n    <li>Many stores use blue paint on the walls, as it has a serene effect on the customers.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Connect green hues with a sense of luck and harmony. Imbue your art, interiors, and other creative projects with a sense of luck, health, and positivity by including the color green. Choose from different green tones to convey this message, whether you’re painting a bedroom or designing the backdrop for a website. Before you decide on a final color scheme, note that green can also be attributed to jealous emotions.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-11.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Since green is associated with luck and wealth, use a shade of this color when designing a website for a financial consulting firm, or an investment agency.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Generate positive, fun vibes with the color yellow. Warm yellow is a great option when designing a friendly, engaging backdrop, or logo. People tend to associate brightness, happiness, and sunny imagery with the color yellow, which can make it a great option for a classroom, gym, or other interior. Since yellow is especially bright, use it sparingly as a backdrop for websites and other forms of media with a lot of text.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-12.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Yellow is a color with a lot of intensity, so it can generate a lot of strong emotions from a viewer.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Embrace originality and optimism with orange tones. Select this warm color to create an engaging, enthusiastic presentation. If you’re trying to bring attention to an aspect of your creative project, opt for some shade of orange to draw in the eye. Additionally, you can use this color to generate feelings of warmth and excitement.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-13.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you’re trying to start a cooking channel on YouTube, try using a shade of orange in your logo. This could help provide an energetic attitude to your channel.</li> \n    <li>People tend to have divisive opinions about the color orange. Don’t be surprised if some people either really enjoy or really dislike its use in different designs.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Demonstrate passion and excitement with the color red. Use the color red to your advantage when designing a bedroom, eating area, or other intense creative project. Note that people tend to feel amplified around this color, whether they’re feeling eager and excited or passionate and angry. Opt for red in your creative projects whenever you’re trying to make a statement, or when you’re trying to appeal to an intense, serious audience.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-14.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The color red is associated with different things. While some people attribute the color to romance and love, others connect it to dangerous feelings and situations.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Associate calmness and intuition with pink. Add a soft, romantic attitude to your art, interior, or brand identity with a splash of pink. Note the feminine and sensual associations people have with the color pink, even if they’re connected to common stereotypes. If you’re trying to create a romantic atmosphere in your creative project, opt for pink, as opposed to passionate red or energetic yellow.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-15.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if you’re designing a website for a floral business, using a pink color scheme to cater to hopeless romantics and similar clientele.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Create an aura of fantasy and mystery with purple hues. Embrace a sense of royalty and intrigue by adding different shades of purple into your projects. Note the historical significance of purple, and how it’s typically associated with wealthy, royal concepts and individuals. If you’re working on a project that caters naturally to a person’s sense of imagination, a purple color scheme is a great option for you to consider.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Practice-Color-Theory#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Practice-Color-Theory-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Practice Color Theory Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-16.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you’re working on a piece of art with a mysterious, mystical vibe, try using different shades of purple in the backdrop, or incorporate the color throughout the design.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Practice-Color-Theory&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.verywellmind.com/the-color-psychology-of-purple-2795820\">https://www.verywellmind.com/the-color-psychology-of-purple-2795820</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"fe06cdb99189947d88aab12485ecae3f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn42@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-03-48-049_0d66300519fe1249.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":37718,"destBytes":24694,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn42@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-03-48-049_0d66300519fe1249.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-2.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn68@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-10-306_a8a69d1fa2cc08e4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-3.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn91@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-11-307_2b219a13d3cdec5f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-4.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn4@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-11-327_f527b23733d8b8df.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-5.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn35@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-12-366_7b8aa6a2408c9460.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-6.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn39@2020_4/2020/09/16/05-04-09-016_3c7aa4c06b526e7a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-7.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn33@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-06-133_6ac10f9cc98abd51.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-8.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn60@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-12-625_0b34f0b6363b53b9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-9.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn68@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-11-994_f4a13edf142bb274.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-10.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn96@2020_1/2020/09/16/05-04-12-249_5dad2d637d33b52f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-11.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn96@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-06-191_ea1d7f59e4624fd4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-12.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn87@2020_6/2020/09/16/05-04-10-374_9546106ab231d340.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-13.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn60@2020_5/2020/09/16/05-04-07-407_0a133af6db4e3d2a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-14.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn36@2020_2/2020/09/16/05-04-13-147_0675c5d9a681e507.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-15.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn32@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-10-024_903e0cad5ffc7699.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Practice-Color-Theory-Step-16.jpg/aid11584751-v4-728px-Practice-Color-Theory-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn80@2020_3/2020/09/16/05-04-11-199_3b270154a5e6cb30.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600232627622},{"createdTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","updatedTime":"2020-09-16 13:03:47","title":"How to Do Dirty Keto","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>The keto diet restricts how many carbs you eat so that your body enters a state called “ketosis\" and burns fat. Clean keto can be tough to follow because there are strict rules about food quality and where it comes from. Dirty keto is a little easier because it allows you to eat any foods you want as long as you stick the fat to protein to carb ratio. If you want to try keto but the clean approach seems intimidating, give dirty keto a try! You may not want to do dirty keto in the long-term because it isn't super healthy, but it can be a great way to lose weight before switching to a healthier diet in the long run. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Dirty-Keto&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Dirty-Keto&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Reaching Ketosis\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reaching-Ketosis\">Reaching Ketosis</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Limit your daily carbs to less than 50 g per day. Slashing the number of carbs you eat every day is the foundation of keto whether you’re doing it clean or dirty. To stay under 50 g of carbs daily, cut starches, bread, grains, and sugars from your diet. Carbs should make up no more than 5-10% of your daily calories.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keto is a low-carb high-fat diet. The goal of keto is to put your body into a state called “ketosis” which forces your body to use fat as its primary energy source, rather than burning carbs and sugar for energy.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Other common carbs include baked goods, sweets, pasta, breakfast cereals, starchy vegetables like potatoes, beans, most fruit, and beer.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make sure 70-80% of your daily caloric intake comes from fats. Eating fat is important because ketosis forces your body to use fat as its main energy source. Fat basically replaces carbs as your body’s fuel. Clean keto has a lot of rules about the type and quality of the fat you eat, but dirty keto is more relaxed. Pretty much any kind of fat is fair game. Meat, butter, and bacon? Yes, please!<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-2.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The exact number of grams you consume depends on your weight, height, gender, and activity level. Use an online keto calculator to help you figure out exactly how much you need. For example, try <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://calculo.io/keto-calculator\">https://calculo.io/keto-calculator</a>.</li> \n    <li>Dirty keto is a little controversial because it doesn’t focus on healthy food options. You’ll lose weight in the short-term, but over time you might run into issues like high cholesterol.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Even if you're not strict about it, it's still best to include healthy fats in your diet, such as avocados, olive oil, and almonds.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Adjust your diet so that 10-20% of your calories come from protein. Keto isn’t a high protein diet, so don’t go overboard with how much protein you eat every day. Protein should only make up about 10-20% of your caloric intake. If you eat too much, your body turns the excess into sugar, which is basically a carbohydrate.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-3.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use an online keto calculator to determine exactly how many grams of protein you need to eat every day: <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://calculo.io/keto-calculator\">https://calculo.io/keto-calculator</a>.</li> \n    <li>For dirty keto, get most of your protein from animal sources like beef, pork, chicken, and turkey.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Be ready for a few temporary symptoms known as the \"keto flu.<b>\"</b> Keto flu isn’t actually a contagious virus, don’t worry. It’s just the name for the group of symptoms most people experience in the first 1-2 weeks of doing keto. Nausea, fatigue, headache, foggy brain, irritability, difficulty sleeping, and constipation are the most common symptoms.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-4.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keto flu usually passes after a week or so, so hang in there and ride it out!</li> \n    <li>In the long-run, you may find that following a keto diet actually gives you energy and helps improve your focus.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use blood or urine test strips to measure the ketone levels in your body. To figure out if you’ve reached ketosis, use a test to measure your ketones. Urine and blood testing strips are available online and in many drug stores. Urine tests are cheaper, but blood tests are more accurate.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-5.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The recommended range for ketosis is 1.5 to 3.0 mmol/l.</li> \n    <li>You might test your ketone levels weekly when you're first starting out. Once you get the hang of keto, you only need to test yourself occasionally to make sure you're on track.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Allow occasional cheat meals if you do dirty keto. Going over your carb allowance kicks you out of ketosis, but dirty keto does make room for occasional cheat days and slip-ups. If you can’t resist the cravings, allow yourself to indulge without guilt. It’s important to get right back on your diet, though! The goal of keto is to maintain ketosis.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-6.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Remember: if you cheat and eat carbs, you have to start your diet again to regain ketosis.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Cheat days and cheat meals aren't allowed in clean keto.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Dirty-Keto&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Choosing Keto-Friendly Foods\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Choosing-Keto-Friendly-Foods\">Choosing Keto-Friendly Foods</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Prioritize the carb/fat/protein ratio every time you make a food choice. Dirty keto provides wiggle room when it comes to your actual food options, but properly balancing the number of carbs, fat, and protein you eat every day is non-negotiable for both clean and dirty keto. Remember, 5-10% of your daily calories can come from carbs, 70-80% should come from fats, and proteins should make up that final 10-20%.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use an online keto calculator to figure out exactly how many grams you need for each food group.</li> \n    <li>A keto app can make it easier for you to track your carbs, fat, and protein every day.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Eat keto-approved packaged or processed foods in moderation. In clean keto, these types of foods are a big no-no. Thankfully, dirty keto is a little more relaxed and much more convenient! Keep in mind that prepackaged and processed foods aren‘t good for your long-term health, though.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup> Enjoy foods like:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-8.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Plain cheeseburgers without the bun</li> \n    <li>Artificial sweeteners</li> \n    <li>Processed oils and proteins</li> \n    <li>Low-carb snack foods, like potato or tortilla chips and cookies</li> \n    <li>Pork rinds and beef jerky</li> \n    <li>Watch out for bloating and inflammation since prepackaged/processed foods tend to be high in sodium.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consume your daily fat grams by eating any high-fat foods you want. Eating enough fat every day is important because your body is using that fat as fuel. Dirty keto doesn't have any restrictions on where you get your fat grams. Butter, margarine, vegetable oil, vegetable shortening, full-fat dairy, and nuts are all on the menu. As long as 70-80% of your daily calories are coming from fat, you’re in the zone!<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-9.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s important to work some healthy options in there, too. Healthy sources recommended for clean keto include olive oil, ghee, coconut oil, nuts, nuts, seeds, and avocados.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get protein from high-quality sources but don’t stress over it. Dirty keto allows any kind of protein you want. Protein is only 10-20% of your diet, though, so don’t stress too much over making perfect choices as long as you meet your daily requirement. Pretty much any kind of poultry, dairy, red meat, lunch meat, jerky, fish, and eggs is fair game on dirty keto.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-10.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Consider including healthier protein options in your diet occasionally. \"Clean\" protein includes organic poultry, dairy, meat, salmon, and eggs produced without hormones or antibiotics. Ideally, meat is minimally processed and ethically sourced.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try to incorporate some high-fiber veggies every day on dirty keto. If a diet without any vegetables at all sounds too good to be true, that’s because it is! Even if you're doing dirty keto, you still need to eat some vegetables so that you get plenty of nutrients and fiber. High-fiber veggies like broccoli, cauliflower, kale, romaine lettuce, and asparagus are the most nutrient-dense options, so aim for those.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-11.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cooking veggies in butter or adding a little cheese on top can make them more palatable and help you meet your daily fat and protein requirements.</li> \n    <li>Small portions of strawberries, blackberries, and raspberries are also approved for dirty keto if you want a fruit fix.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Eat foods to replenish your electrolyte levels every day. Low-carb diets, including both clean and dirty keto, deplete your body of 4 important electrolytes: sodium, potassium, magnesium, and calcium. It's important to eat low-carb foods that are high in electrolytes to rebalance your levels and avoid feeling fatigued and ill.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Sprinkle pink Himalayan salt on your food to replenish your sodium.</li> \n    <li>Salmon, nuts, avocados, leafy green veggies, and mushrooms are high in potassium.</li> \n    <li>Eat calcium-dense foods like dark leafy greens, broccoli, salmon, and sardines.</li> \n    <li>Replenish magnesium by eating leafy greens, dark chocolate, pumpkin seeds, Swiss chard, and nuts.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drink plenty of liquids to stay hydrated on dirty keto. Keto can make you dehydrated, so fluid intake is important. Juices and sodas are off the table, even if you're doing dirty keto, because they have carbs and sugar. The best choices are water, herbal tea, and green vegetable juice.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Do Dirty Keto Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-13.jpg/aid12084841-v4-728px-Do-Dirty-Keto-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Occasionally drinking chai or coffee drinks made with coconut milk and sugar-free syrup is fine for dirty keto.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Dirty-Keto&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Check out keto-friendly food lists online or keto recipe books to add some variety to your diet and prevent boredom and cravings.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Dirty-Keto&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Most experts don’t recommend dirty keto as a permanent diet solution because it isn't healthy enough and the long-term effects aren't well understood. Use it to lose weight in the short-term or work with a dietician to ensure you're meeting your nutrition requirements.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Dirty-Keto#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Do-Dirty-Keto&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol
